generation: Another week flew by. I drove by the new house yesterday, and the front window was covered in boxes. We may get the keys at closing, and I am getting so excited. If all goes well this week, we will be set for closing a week from Wednesday. I was up until after 3:00 a.m. last night watching movies with Bethany. There has been a lot of movie-watching happening here lately. Here's my rundown: last night we watched "Thirteen," a movie every mother of a teen should see. It was better than I expected. Then we watched "Gigli," and, yes, it was just as bad as the media said, but we had to watch it ourselves.

Summer TV used to be a dead zone full of repeats. However, now there are two great new shows I have been watching religiously for the last week. "Blow Out" has the gayest concept ever, seemingly with zero gay people in sight. Hairstylist Jonathan Antin wants to build a second location for his incredibly popular West Hollywood salon, now in Beverly Hills. Normally, no one would care—not me, but as I was flipping through the channels, I caught a glimpse of Jonathan, equally narcissistic and dull, looking at an empty space on Rodeo Drive. He declared, "I am going to build here the greatest salon in the history of the world ever!" and I was hooked. Not since "Rocco" have I found such a compelling TV moron.

What a week... My right shoulder has tendonitis, right under my shoulder blade. When I move my arm too much, especially with a mouse on a computer, it really hurts. I can’t move it much now because I was busy updating my website and working on other online tasks. I can barely draw anything. Lack of sleep worsens my pain. I'm not too happy right now, but I'll get better. My mom's surgery went okay. Her eyesight has somewhat returned; she can see fuzzy shapes and make out colors. Other than that, she's still nearly blind. Hopefully, she'll fully regain her vision soon.

Encountering the kindness of strangers... Attempted laundry today with the kids in tow and realized how quickly the simplest things can become an ordeal. I also learned how remarkably sweet strangers can be for no reason other than wanting to be kind. Trust me—it wasn't like they were hoping to impress me or anything. I was covered in kid drool and wearing my 'wash-day' outfit... Also, I'm not entirely sure when I'll be bathing again, so there was no olfactory incentive! I am currently doing two things: composing a post and watching collected No Doubt videos. Both of these things I am doing while sitting at my desk in my room.

So it is 11:14 PM MST, and here I sit in my bedroom fixing the personal computer of the personnel director from my job. Not that I mind, but I wonder sometimes how often I find myself fixing someone else's computer as a favor. I'm glad to help in this way, but where is the line drawn between kindness and being taken advantage of? The last couple of weeks, I've been staying up late, so I was looking forward to sleeping early until I realized it was best to get this computer back to its owner. No rest for the weary, right? I found myself watching Joe Schmo 2 again tonight.

Remind me, what did I write about before this? A continuation in the "Is this a date?" saga. So, after the weird lunch, my confidence shook. I forgot to share an important piece of the story. Before Pat arrives for lunch, Dustin begins talking about what a nice guy Pat is and how he's trying to find a girlfriend for him. I'm listening, nodding, and realizing that we're talking more about finding Dustin's best friend a girl than discussing whatever you discuss with a stranger over pink lemonade. I excused myself to the bathroom, looked in the mirror, and silently asked myself: am I being pawned off to the other guy? Is this what happens now?

I would like everyone to think before they act. Actually, I wish each and every person in the world would think before getting out of bed in the morning and make a commitment to keep thinking all day. If they aren't prepared to, I'd strongly prefer that they hop back in bed and drift off to an eternal slumber. I'm tired of dealing with stupid people. I'm not the smartest person in the world, and I'm not talking about things that require much brainpower, so I feel it's fair to criticize the profoundly ignorant. Let's see if I can limit this rant to a few specific types and save some for another day. Sound good? Great.

Two problems with the scenario outlined in my previous post: 1. Although Bush is stimulating the economy, he is doing so ineffectively. Robert Rubin informed NPR's Marketplace today that Bush could have achieved the same stimulus effect without the long-term debt hangover by implementing different tax cuts—temporary cuts benefiting low and middle-income individuals. It'll come to you... 2. We cannot give Republicans control only in wartime because they've ingeniously concocted an endless, global 'war on terrorism.'

'She's saying I'm on the run, I'm chasing guys for fun' ~The Offspring. I haven’t updated in a while because there’s not much to report. Went to the Cove to see Supernothing; they were good as usual. Got to chill with Tiago. On Saturday, I worked and then went out with Joe and Rach. Met up with Steve, Tiago, and Tom. Came home around 11:45 PM and woke up at 6:45 AM for a meet. I got there a little late, but it went well. I didn’t fall on floor, placed second on floor and vault, third on beam, and scored 29.45 overall, which is decent since my meets improve as the season progresses.

Do you ever have one of those moments when you begin to reflect on life? Like you're sitting in math class, bored out of your skull, and you wonder what exactly goes on in your brain that makes you understand math? You realize you exist, you're in math class, and you wonder why. Then it hits you—the fact that you're off on this random train of thought feels incredibly pathetic. Ever had that happen? I hate that. You know what else I hate? Block schedules. Who would ever come up with that idea? Anyone can see sitting through a two-and-a-half-hour class in any subject is cruel and unusual punishment.

I think Monopoly has run its course in my life, and I vow never to lay my hands on that iron (not a hot one, but the piece in the game) again. Tonight, Andy beat me by a few small dollars and won the game, or maybe I let him win because he’s leaving in a few short hours, and I wanted him to feel good on his last night here. However the story goes, it can't compare to this Texas-sized headache I have at the moment. I've taken some Aleve, and I must say that they are doing the trick. All I need now is some well-deserved rest and relaxation; your telephone's the one that helped me wrap the cord around your neck... At the drive-in.

Well... Today's been a long day. We drove home from Indiana. I guess I'll have to be selective about what I write because I could take up a lot of time and space, and I just don't have the energy. First off, I have to say that camp was awesome and even better than I could have expected. God has been doing so much in my life lately, and it's just amazing. I've turned over a new leaf, I guess, but back to the beginning. We arrived at the Twiggs' house on Friday evening and stayed until we left for camp on Monday. Most of our time was spent going to the fair, church, a parade, Walmart, and watching movies.

Today is my last day of summer vacation! Ugh! And I have a dentist appointment at 9. I hate that, but I'd rather get it over with than try to schedule it during the first month of my surgery rotation. I'm definitely nervous, scared, jittery, and anything else you can think of for not wanting to go to school. This is going to be a whole new ball game for me. As a perfectionist, I love excelling at everything I do. But starting new things is tough. I hate being a pawn (like I told Cassie: "I'm going to be the only pawn on the chessboard who insists on moving like a knight"), and I hate not knowing what's going on.

Arun Shourie discusses how the current governor of Uttar Pradesh had warned as early as 1996 about the potential threat of a "third Islamic state" emerging in the subcontinent. T.V. Rajeswar, the former head of the Intelligence Bureau and the current governor of Uttar Pradesh, predicted this serious threat in a series of articles published in the Hindustan Times in 1996. Shourie makes a compelling argument by asking if acknowledging that Rajeswar, not Advani, authored these warnings lends them credibility, or if it leads to the conclusion that Rajeswar is a covert communalist who should not serve as governor.

Attitude: bored; mood: indifferent, but looking forward to tonight. It's been a long, hard day in the trenches here today, folks, leaving almost no time to write for you readers. However, it's good to see Tigger (now Akcron) taking up the reins herself, making an appearance and discussing things. Yesterday was Shakespeare on the Green—a lovely play—but I had to leave before the closing curtain, which was disappointing. Hopefully, someday I'll see an entire Shakespeare play. But I digress. Akcron is right about the shower issues; it’s frustrating. In terms of laughing at her in the shower, you have to admit, the look people get when committing self-torture can be pretty entertaining.

Suddenly, for the past two days, I have been overwhelmed with intense exhaustion. Bone-deep exhaustion. Last evening, I went home and slept, only waking when my mother called around eight-thirty. When I awoke, it was dark, and I hadn’t turned on the lights, so for a few seconds, I couldn't determine the time or date; it was just my mother’s voice in the darkness as I grappled with reality. I wonder why I’m feeling so drained... The weather is nice this morning. It was drizzling when I arrived. Although in Calcutta, I hear it’s been raining for the past three days.

Last night was the worst. I threw away the sweater I was knitting. I only had about 14 inches. I lost probably $10 worth of yarn (it's $8 a skein). It had too many stitches by the time I reached the armholes, and the mohair was knotting itself together as I knitted, so frogging (ripping out rows) didn’t work well. The yarn broke a lot. I didn’t even swear, which is unusual for me. I just morosely unraveled it and listened to season two of Sex and the City (way to go, library!). Then I got sick of it and threw it away. I suppose I could say I learned a lot while attempting this sweater.

Last night in class, we discussed this week's assigned reading, "Getting Back into Place: Toward a Renewed Study of the Place-World" by Edward S. Casey. The first chapter covers “implacement” and the second, “displacement.” In the first chapter, Casey argues that our contemporary world and culture revolve around time as the situating force: we are running out of time, we have saved time, we are just in time. He suggests that using place as the center of culture provides a more grounded community. (This is a very rough summation, provided as a disclaimer in case my professor or any other classmate reads this post.) So far, this book is the first reading that has grabbed me by the proverbial shoulders.

Whatever they put into freeze pops to achieve those colors, there should be some sort of warning: may make your life a bit bizarre. While giggling is good, one wonders if we would have found ourselves up that fire escape drinking beer in the fierce wind had we not been eating them earlier. Who could possibly have guessed that within these pages were the special offers of a lifetime? Not I, for certain. I list but a few: buy 36 permanent marker pens, get a stunt kite. Buy 30 lever arch files, get a barbecue.

Currently listening to: "The Little Drummer Boy" by Stevan Pasero. And now, my post… Senate Republicans: okay, hands up—who watched the 39-hour judicial nominations spectacle last week? I know I didn't. Well, okay—I did tune in once or twice. The entire colossal waste of time was orchestrated by Republicans who, upset that Democrats wouldn't approve four of Bush's more extreme justices, were trying to score political points with a multi-day display. This was a good weekend. I enjoyed a lot of nature, and after a long time, I listened to a lot of Nevermore (something I should have started doing much earlier) and read extensively. I finished three books over the weekend: Bruce Sterling's *Heavy Weather*, Larry Niven's *World of Ptavvs*, and Octavia Butler's *Parable of the Sower*. *Heavy Weather* was an engaging cyberpunk adventure set in a near-future USA devastated by global warming and widespread anarchy. While it was clever, well-paced, and altogether convincing, I must confess that I didn't come away with any truly significant sensations about the story or the characters. Though both are well constructed and vividly depicted—it's a good book, but not a great one, I guess.

Fall 1974: I was attempting for what felt like the 13th time to fight my way through the second chapter of my high school algebra book. I was not then nor am I now a math person. I hate math. I am math phobic. You get the picture. As I struggled to make sense of algebra, the doorbell rang. I put down my book and went to open the door. No one was there. Great. I returned to my studies and, just as I was finding a little glimmer of understanding buried in my subconscious, the doorbell rang again. Bam, just like that, my breakthrough disappeared. I went to the door, and once again, no one was there. Just what a struggling math student needs—an uninvited practical joker.

This past week has been nothing short of exhausting. I spent Tuesday to Thursday finishing the move to my new classroom, which is bigger and closer to my grade-level team. These are important factors to consider as I spend hours preparing my room for this year. Had I known I was going to move before the end of the school year, I would have discarded many books and supplies I no longer use. Unfortunately, it all came with me. So, this week was spent moving, unpacking, and purging profusely. I have to thank my teammate Jill for helping with all of this. She was still teaching this month in my old room, so she and her lovely students moved almost my entire room for me!

You can't help it, you can't evade it: a piece of you will always live in me. Even if I never carried your child, even if I was never married to you, even if I was never an official pair to you... I loved you immensely, and to this day the feeling echoes through my heart. I will always be reminded of those few nights we spent together, hearts and limbs entwined in a soul-embrace, drenched in the salty darkness of an evening by the beach... Or a kiss under the rain. Whenever I feel a dark glass puncturing my heart, you will be there. That piece of you... Bleeding the eternal love that once lived in me... And still remains.

I'm uneasy. Investigative reporting feels very wrong to me. Or let me rephrase that, the article I'm working on and its consequences are not exactly something I'm comfortable with. Perhaps it is because I don't believe in it enough to fully engage. The angst behind it. The full-out passion to question. I've grown up in a country where you don't ask questions. Really, you just don't. They punish you for that. They imprison you under internal security acts. I'm not used to this freedom of speech...not used to questioning out loud. We had an outing yesterday with my coworkers from the bank. We went to Guintubdan, La Carlota. It was the first visit for most of us. We trekked to the falls, a 30-minute walk. We were all out of breath, but we made it. The water was icy cold, numbing our bodies. We stayed for less than an hour before heading to the nearby waterfalls, another 30-minute trek. The trip was worth it, as the falls were calming, and the entire scene was breathtaking. It felt like becoming one with nature. Soaking in the cold water was like communing with Mother Earth. The cold air and water lulled us into tranquility.

Some people are quick to connect this dot: the Organization for Security and Cooperation in Europe was invited to monitor the election by the State Department. The observers will come from the OSCE's Office for Democratic Institutions and Human Rights. It will be the first time such a team has been present for a U.S. presidential election. With this dot: a baker's dozen of Congressional Democrats, including four New Yorkers, have petitioned U.N. Secretary-General Kofi Annan to send international observers to Florida for this year's presidential balloting. I humbly disagree. Based on the information available, the OSCE seems to be coming here to learn from the U.S. election process, not to oversee it, contrary to the original partisan and immature call for U.N. intervention.

GOP faces criticism as naturalization ceremonies in Jacksonville are relocated after complaints about GOP activists registering new citizens as Republicans. The citizenship ceremony there seemed routine, with nearly 200 people becoming new Americans. Before leaving the June 29 event, an immigration official encouraged attendees to visit a voter registration table—a common feature at such ceremonies. However, this table was unusual: Republican volunteers were handing out forms with the party affiliation box pre-checked to enroll new voters as GOP members. Linda Cross found it suspicious while witnessing her husband, Dario Cruz, take his citizenship oath.

I liked the idea of that as an offense—perhaps a way to avoid being burned as a witch. As a non-American blogger, I've been a bit hesitant to engage in some of these discussions, especially about flags. However, since I initiated the subject (not the flag-burning), I suppose I should comment. Firstly, I believe that having a law against flag-burning is completely absurd. Hello, I saw Troy tonight with my family and was not impressed. I'm too tired to delve into specifics, but I do think it had potential. However, too much energy was spent on the set (which was magnificent) and not enough on creating a solid tone and theme. It retold the story, but was not particularly gripping, and I didn't feel like I gained anything from watching it. The character development was rather weak. Additionally, I thought the score was poor, essentially a knock-off of Gladiator. Gladiator used the background music of a moaning woman effectively because it complemented a genuinely gripping narrative.

Urllink introduces the latest atom/RDF/RSS reader, PulpFiction 1.0, from Freshly Squeezed Software. It boasts plenty of native app features. It's important to note that it isn't free, which is a hot topic online. You can try it for 15 days, then either switch back or purchase it for $25 if preferred. A standout feature is that each post acts as a separate entity, allowing users to move, store, label, and delete them. This capability is likely to please news trackers. As expected, it supports OPML import and export.

While I personally cannot recommend this game, it wasn't absolutely terrible. The gunplay is decent, as long as you have the money to purchase gun parts, which constitutes my main complaint: it's pay-to-win. If I could get past that, the game would be enjoyable, as the hardsuit is fun and HRV is an excellent idea. I'd choose this game over any Call of Duty title any day, but its pay-to-win microtransaction format is off-putting for me. If you are comfortable with this model, then by all means, have fun. But if you're like me and dislike pay-to-win games, just let this one slide; it's not our cup of tea.

Though not flawless, this game has been immensely enjoyable. The save system and potential for sudden death can be frustrating. During my first playthrough, I lost my main character around hour 10 of a 20-hour session. I wished I could reload a save at that point. I've since used a third-party mod/save tool to prevent catastrophic failures. Additionally, the aiming reticle is small, and the zoom is weak. Despite these issues, it's been a blast. I'm not typically a zombie fan, but the mix of strategy, missions, and first-person shooter/beat-em-up elements is fantastic. I've been playing as often as possible... Just one more mission, just one more supply run—or I'm escaping to a safe spot before closing the game.

An absolutely great strategy game! Having played every other wargame (European Escalation and ALB), I must say this one fits well. The number of units is impressive—though I'm not sure exactly how many, there are a ton! The graphics are beautiful, the sounds are great, and the gameplay is epic. The in-game chat box at the main menu is entertaining as well—I'm not kidding. However, if you're new to the strategy genre, it might take some time to master. Don't get upset; you will lose units. Just plan ahead and always have anti-air and anti-tank.

I was negatively biased towards this game before I played it. I wasn’t even sure about buying it. I don’t know, the whole portal gun and portals thing seemed weird to me even though I like science fiction. Boy, was I wrong. The jokes and voice acting are phenomenal—just amazing. It’s not cheesy (okay, it’s sometimes cheesy). Different story characters each have their own sense of humor. Those characters truly have different personalities. And the level design; it's just rad. By the way, I never played the first Portal game. One of these days, I’m planning to if I can spare the time. I would never have played it if I hadn’t played the sequel.

Let's start with the pros and cons, followed by my thoughts on the game. + Some of the best characters + Good story + Lots of content + Customizable character (you can be male or female) + You can have a relationship with most of your companions (yes, fangirls, you can have a love interest) - Bad graphics (I don't think graphics really matter anyway) - Awkward love scenes - Invisible walls - There's one mission that, in my opinion, was boring, but everyone has different tastes -+ This isn't really bad or good, but for those who care, your protagonist can't talk. Now for my thoughts: I love this game. It is probably one of the best RPGs or games in general I have ever played. If you're an RPG fan, you probably already have this game.

Yes, this is a nostalgia trip for thirty-somethings who remember (at least in the UK) watching the ever-irritating Timmy Mallet just for the five-minute Transformers cartoon. The voice actors for Optimus, Megatron, Bumblebee, and many others are back and instantly recognizable. The distinctive cartoon transformation sound is present. Graphically, the cel-shaded presentation is perfect, and very, very Generation One. But aside from that, it's actually a very fun game. The combat mechanics are exceptionally well executed. Transforming mid-fight is often necessary and seamlessly integrated into combos, making it quite different from High Moon's excellent War for/Fall of Cybertron games. Another distinction is the heavy focus on melee combat, but some enemies (e.g., Seekers) require a switch to a ranged blaster.

I downloaded the game and played for a while, but it was nothing special. I spent more time trying to log in than actually playing. There's a bug where it says there's an update to the terms of service, and when you click 'accept,' it just pops up again. You have to restart the client for it to work. Why do I need to link my Steam and Gface accounts? They say it's for DLC, but why is that necessary? It's also irreversible, so now a company I don't care about has access to my Steam information. The game itself is mediocre. It's recognizable as a COD clone, except somehow they made the gunplay worse.

4K+ at 60fps (GTX 970), dual audio options, and includes Neptune gear. What's not to love? Excellent port and a great entry point if new to the series. Just keep in mind there is lots of (skippable) talking. As usual, I would suggest using a gamepad, but I had no problems with key/mouse setup, both completely rebindable. Price is about right and wouldn't have been unhappy about a purchase. More than half the DLC is included free, which is still plenty to play with. Recommended game to all JRPG/anime/visual novel fans, provided you don't mind long breaks between the action. Cheers.

I experienced no performance problems even at release, and after all these patches, it plays extremely well. In my opinion, this is a great and fun game, although the format can be somewhat irritating, with the free-roam city area repopulating with new enemies every time you progress the story. I particularly enjoyed the 'dual play' segments where you can play as Batman and another character. The ability to use the controller for most parts of the game, but switch to mouse and keyboard for the tank combat segments, was greatly appreciated. Driving the Batmobile around the free-roam city, especially when chasing the APC commanders, is quite enjoyable once you master skidding around corners. When you master that, driving around the city becomes a real pleasure!

An excellent AAA FPS shooter—that’s the bottom line. It looks, sounds, and plays superbly with outstanding FPS mechanics, an engaging story, cool characters, impeccable voice acting, and a fantastic soundtrack. However, it’s not for the faint-hearted—some cutscenes are quite intense. But when a game is so great overall, its flaws become more apparent, and here are the ones I noticed: - No SLI support—I had to shelve the game until I upgraded my card, as it ran poorly on my old dual GPU GTX 590. Ensure you have a fairly decent single GPU card. - Frustratingly small obstacles are often unclimbable.

English is not my native language. I am Dutch, so please excuse any typing or grammatical mistakes in my review of this fantastic game. I will break down this review into a few categories: graphics, controls, sound, gameplay, and replayability. Graphics: The game is set in a comic-like style, with slick visuals and no unnecessary details. The color schemes are nice and effective for this game. The graphics can be set on 'high' without stressing your system. I run this game on an i5 Pentium processor with an NVIDIA GeForce 710m card and 8GB memory, and it operates smoothly on Windows 8.1. Controls: The game can be played with a keyboard and mouse or with an Xbox controller.

You can see by the hours I put into this game that I enjoy it. This is everything I wished a search game from COD would be. But don't buy this game thinking it's like COD, Battlefield, or any other shooter. It's in a class of its own and should be treated as such. Can't tell you how many times I hear new players complain about getting killed quickly. It's not like that doesn't happen in real life or anything. Edit: I've been playing this game for awhile now and thrown all kinds of money at it. One of the best multiplayer games around. A good choice when you're not feeling CS:GO.

I'm two hours in and thoroughly enjoying this game. It's hilarious. The gameplay is solid, the art design is beautiful, and the music is surprisingly high quality and fitting. The story and world keep me interested, and the puzzles are fun. However, the standout feature is the comedy. If you've played RPGs since their inception, you'll enjoy the jokes, parodies, and references. Even if you're new to RPGs, the humor is entertaining. If you've played Final Fantasy 7 or X, you must try this game. I had to pause after two hours because I was laughing and smiling so much. What a delight so far!

I'm really sorry. I try to be supportive of free-to-play games and indie developers, but I really didn't enjoy this game. The description sounded perfect for me, but the execution did nothing for me. I love puzzle and exploration games, but I found this one completely unintuitive. Even after looking up how to progress, I simply didn’t find the gameplay fun. It also lacks a pause button, or if it does, I never found it. Considering that many sequences in the game are timed, this seems like a critical oversight. I also feel like this game is more cut scene than it is game, and I end up just sitting around drumming my fingers a lot.

This game... Phew, where do I even begin? It was breathtaking, from the story to the graphics; I was completely captivated. The narrative wasn't just a tale; it genuinely made me feel like I was that character, trying to uncover what came next in their journey. The gameplay was outstanding, and I discovered a lot about myself, particularly my fear of heights, which was never an issue until the ice caverns. My stomach churned throughout, but I persevered for Uncle Fred! If you created a DLC or a sequel, I would be the first to purchase it and recommend it to everyone I know. Thanks to everyone involved in creating this; you made an absolutely beautiful game.

Sid Meier's Civilization: Beyond Earth is a turn-based game where you build your civilization to achieve a specific goal or "victory." Previously, the series focused on Earth's timeline, progressing through periods like the Stone Age, Medieval Age, and Modern Age. In contrast, this game is set in the future, centered on colonizing a new planet. I enjoy how 2K adopted a fresh approach by introducing new mechanics such as the affinity system and orbital layer. However, these innovations can make the game feel overwhelming at times. I believe the game could be improved by incorporating new artwork, especially regarding the environment you experience during interactions with other leaders.

Great game! Tons of replayability and a very fun zombie survival game! Definitely in my top 5 zombie games ever played. Edit: After playing 60+ hours, I can honestly say this is one of the better, more "realistic" zombie games. It's very much designed like survival horror as you must conserve ammo, treat your own wounds when bleeding out, take pills when infected, etc. Also, I find zombies to feel very natural and are well-animated for a free-to-play game. P.S.: I would recommend getting 1 or 2 friends to play with, but the community is super friendly and you can usually make friends or chat with people in the chat or over voice comms.

02/07/2014 - It's unfortunate I can't fully recommend or enjoy this game. From the brief time I've played it, I know I'd be hooked if it weren't for these two significant issues. No Australian servers mean one red bar puts you at a severe disadvantage and creates unbearable lag. Additionally, when I played the offline training mode, it was also stuttering (how does that even happen?). Coupled with poor ping, it ruins the experience. Everything, including menus, backgrounds, training, and in-game visuals, artifacts excessively. I've never had this issue before with this card and thought it might dislike my overclocking. I returned my GPU to stock settings, yet it made no difference.

Late last night, I finished this. The story itself might not be very deep or intriguing, but the storytelling sets it apart. The atmosphere is immersive, and the many collectibles effectively flesh it out. I learned much about Batman's world, so it was somewhat disappointing that there were so few bosses. However, future games can address this. The combat provides a decent challenge, although leaning towards the easier side. Leveling up Batman felt unsatisfying. The gadgets you upgrade and acquire during the campaign introduce new gameplay mechanics that are quite enjoyable. Gaining access to previously unreachable areas imparts a satisfying sense of progression.

'To the Moon' is no mere game; it is a veritable experience, and one of the best of my life at that. Think Telltale's The Walking Dead is sad? It's no match for To the Moon! Never before have I felt so depressed yet fulfilled over something purely fictional. This masterpiece is the pinnacle of storytelling in my opinion, and the soundtrack is a charming and perfect accompaniment. Yes, the controls are a bit finicky, and the gameplay is not the strong point, but the story is so fantastic that I didn’t care. Plus, the humor of the game is great and does not intrude upon the distinguished nature of the story. The Doctor Who references are endless.

Bastion is a brilliant game with an exceptional storyline. Set after a calamity, you begin rebuilding on the bastion. The game offers significant choices, like what to construct for an advantage, which weapons to use, and which power-ups to apply. You can also select drinks for bonus effects. The art style and music are fantastic, with vibrant visuals that defy typical apocalyptic dullness. Best of all, the game features narration based on your actions. For instance, if you pick up a weapon then switch it in the armory, the narration will comment on you taking the new weapon.

I originally bought this game during its early development phase, when the only currency was spacebux, and there was no 'tech tree'. This was when the game was at its best. All the guns were equally overpowered, so there were no issues with imbalance; everyone could eliminate anyone at any time. The game used to offer unlimited gun slots and five loadouts. You would think that a game boasting 'bajillions of guns' would provide more than 6 weapon slots and 3 loadouts before requiring payment for additional options. At one point, I had about 3 pages worth of guns and was planning new ideas for more, because for me, that's where the fun was.

This game was a surprising gem. Often, rave reviews are misleading, but in this case, they truly capture the fun of this neat little game. It is an intriguing mix between a classic 2D platformer and a MOBA, executed with style. I found myself enjoying characters I wouldn't typically enjoy in other MOBA games. Expecting this trait to continue, I decided to try a melee tank anyway. I was pleasantly surprised by the experience and ended up exploring more as they were unlocked from playing. The art style and interface are charmingly unique. Now, I use one of the characters as my avatar and created a wallpaper from a card set for the game.

I just started playing, but I love this game. I put on my headphones and lose myself for hours. It's been awhile since a game had that effect on me. The music sets the mood, sound effects are spot on, and controls are perfect. I look forward to every combat, and they've optimized it extremely well. I had doubts about the naval combat system, but it is so much fun to lay waste to multiple fleets! The only way to lose is to fail to retreat. If combat looks overwhelming, just retreat, regroup, and counter-assault. Thanks, devs, for an awesome experience!

The reboot of the Devil May Cry franchise has introduced many changes, particularly for the series' protagonist, Dante. While fans of the original series may be upset by the changes to their beloved character, it's undeniably for the better, as this new game by Ninja Theory demonstrates. DMC is an ideal entry point for newcomers to the series, showcasing the origins of an arrogant, cynical Dante and chronicling his journey from cynicism to selflessness. Throughout, the game weaves a clear narrative arc for the new Dante, making him a compelling character to follow. The story follows Dante as he's introduced to the corrupt world he previously chose to ignore.

Where do I begin with this absolutely beautiful game? Its story is utterly charming, brimming with detail, humor, quirky dogs, and secrets. It balances seriousness with humor seamlessly. The character design is exceptional, featuring a diverse array of personalities and intriguing secrets. It stands out from other RPGs by not requiring players to kill, a unique concept in the genre. Drawing inspiration from EarthBound, one of the best RPGs I've encountered, it promises an exceptional experience. The soundtrack is truly the best I've heard in ages.

I recommend this solely because it's free, and it might offer a more enjoyable experience for others. As for my experience, the game did nothing for me. Half the story relies on shock factor. I was not shocked or emotionally moved. Maybe I'm desensitized, or perhaps it was too simple to elicit a reaction. The other half of the game attempts to depict a person in mental decline, dealing with obsession, hallucination, and depression. In theory, it's a cool idea. However, the game took me 10 minutes to complete, even with reading and absorbing every bit of information.

Do I even need to explain why Portal is amazing? Portal is a puzzle game that introduces a concept and then lets you engage. It's an excellent way to challenge your mind while remaining enjoyable. Although this game isn't heavily focused on story, it spawned one of the most popular games of 2011. I still play and complete it when I'm bored, appreciating what gave birth to a legend. Gameplay: Portal's gameplay is quite simple, at least in explanation. You utilize portals to your advantage, alongside buttons that activate parts of the puzzle. There are two types of buttons in the game: one you press and another requiring a cube.

If you can overlook the bugs (I personally encountered only two: one minor and the other quite annoying), both of which have been resolved, I can definitely recommend this space exploration game. One fix increased my FPS from 60-90 to 80-120. Since most reviews focus on specs, I'll include mine: i5 6600k (~200€), Radeon RX480 (~200€), Z170 Pro - Gaming (~150€), 16GB DDR4 RAM (~70€). This ~650€ setup is in the medium price range, albeit quite new, with almost constant 60+ FPS on high settings with Vsync enabled. I genuinely can't believe 90% of the comments saying they have an overkill setup and get 20 FPS.

Remember Age of Mythology? It’s been quite some time since there’s been an RTS game of similar quality. Divinity: Dragon Commander comes impressively close to these benchmarks of my personal favorite RTS games. Coupled with a substantial, risk-like grand strategy mode, it truly hits the mark. I strive not to be overly biased, but the game’s feature allowing you to transform into a dragon—supporting, attacking, and even commanding unit production and direction simultaneously—is impressive. I genuinely appreciate complex RTS games today, like Civ V. However, these games often attempt to incorporate complex mechanics, charts, and resources into a single, intricate game mode.

Undertale comes together to create something greater than the sum of its parts. The graphics are solid for a retro title, and the music is captivating. Paired together, they form truly beautiful and impactful moments. The script ranges from comedic to dramatic to heartbreaking to hopeful, sometimes all at once, while cleverly subverting RPG tropes. And this is without even delving into the world, characters, story, or gameplay... I could write pages about it. Instead, I'll just say: if you like RPGs, play this game. If you like video games, play this game. If you have seven free hours between now and the end of your life, play this game.

I've only had this game for a few months, but in that short time, two DLCs have been released, along with patches that have transformed an already great game into an excellent one. The developers are very active in the community, which is evident in the discussion forums and dev diaries. There is a steep learning curve to the game's mechanics, which I'm still learning; however, this breadth of strategy offers myriad ways to achieve goals and take advantage of situations. In my opinion, the game is almost infinitely replayable. I find myself drawn into every session, regardless of how the playthrough is going.

Warframe is entertaining for the first few hours. Afterward, you'll notice that the game mainly offers repetition in its combat, enemies, and gameplay. The major highlight is the developers' commitment, evident in their semi-frequent updates, adding substantial content, ranging from changes to some of the game's systems to new warframes and other features. It's suitable for casual play. However, it may not captivate you for more than a few months unless you're fond of grinding. The advantage is that the game is free, so I'd recommend giving it a try. If you're seeking a quick fix, try it out.

This game is incredibly boring. I bought it believing it was a PC version of 'Katamari Damacy,' a popular and enjoyable PS2 game. Sadly, it's far from it. In this game, you absorb increasingly larger things to grow bigger and absorb even larger things. However, the gameplay lacks smoothness, the levels are not inventive, and what's present is a surreal horror show. It's not an entertaining horror show but one that leaves you rather depressed, questioning if life is all it should be. Every 'living' creature in this game, from small pets to humans, makes me wonder if the creators were interested in taxidermy.

Alright. Let me explain a few things. As someone very interested in politics, I was intrigued by this game when I first heard about it. I thought, "Oh wow! A simulator of the road to becoming president! That sounds fun!" Well, it really wasn't. The game starts off by requiring you to pick a side: Republican or Democrat, with no option for independent or third-party. A little disappointed but still optimistic, I continued to see what I could do. I will give the game credit: the character customization, although limited, is quite fun to experiment with. It's the only time it's an option to wear your head or not in a campaign. Literally.

Fallout 3's story was superior. Settlements interfere with the storyline to the point where you'll resent managing them instead of engaging with the plot. Some keys are hardcoded and cannot be rebound. Glitches are rampant. At one point, my Pip-Boy vanished permanently, requiring research into console commands to restore it. You don’t have to earn power armor; it’s practically given from the start, with power cores abundantly available in trader shops. The value of power armor has diminished significantly from previous Fallout games. The story is mediocre, and overall, the game is unimpressive, although it doesn't crash every 10 minutes like Fallout 3, making it very stable in comparison. Is it better than Fallout 3? No. Is it better than New Vegas? No. This title was so overhyped for how disappointing it actually is.

My stats (at the time of writing this review): - 8.6 hours to finish - 10 out of 25 collectibles found - zero out of 15 achievements attained What I liked: - Visuals up until the last level (ice caves) - The story, though not remarkable, had an ending (post-credits) that made the time spent on this game somewhat worthwhile What I disliked: - The last level's visuals are uninteresting - The gameplay in the last level becomes frustrating due to increased difficulty, requiring repeated attempts to succeed - Achievements are too challenging, with only 2.1% of players obtaining 13 out of 15!

Pros: +great graphics 

Cons: -bugs (especially in the environment; you might get stuck or your shots may hit an invisible wall despite having a clear line of sight to the enemy) -the game is overly handholding/babysitting -poor AI -enemies always seem to know your location once spotted -enemy precision is frustrating, much like the first Ghost Warrior -terrible checkpoints and saves -unengaging story that I couldn't care less about. I cannot recommend it unless it's 90% off; even then, playing this game feels more like a tedious chore, merely played for the sake of finishing it to move on to the next in my library. Considering the time wasted on the first Ghost Warrior (equally tedious, feeling liberated upon completion), I probably won't finish this one.

Review for 29/11/2015: Do not buy this game, servers are offline. You can't play. No compres este juego, servidores offline. No puedes jugar. While I could play it, I enjoyed it. As the Steve Miller Band songs says...: "Go on, take the money and run." --- English - 73 minutes playing the game. Just an hour in this game, and it's awesome! Some guns are overpowered, and matchmaking can be unfair, but hey, BF3 is worse. Matchmaking pairs newbies with higher-level players weren't real humans; you shoot them in the face, and nothing happens!

It's easy to understand why others enjoy this game, but it wasn't for me. For one, I have a Vive and prefer playing room-scale games with controllers. Additionally, the game's scale is initially awe-inspiring, yet I felt it also hindered my enjoyment. The learning curve and the time required to do anything interesting at the beginning were too steep for me. If I were more patient or had more time for gaming, this might be compelling. However, I lack both, and there are many other VR games I'd prefer to spend my time on.

Without a doubt, my favorite first-person shooter of all time. Run-and-gun style players need not apply. Recoil and ballistics are realistic. Shots to the chest, neck, or head from rifle-caliber weapons usually result in death unless they graze you. Rounds drop over distance, requiring short, controlled bursts to stay on target. There’s no magic ammo pool; reloading halfway will leave you with a pouch full of partial mags. You can't run endlessly. Sprinting for a while affects your aim as you gasp for breath. Rest your weapon on your elbows while prone or on a windowsill to steady your aim. Accuracy suffers when standing.

Let me begin by saying I did not purchase EU when it first came out; I got it on sale, which included EW, so I never experienced the issues some people claimed to have had. I loved that game; it was unforgiving in the early stages but rewarding when you did things right. As for XCOM 2, I love it. The game runs well for me on medium settings, and I have a GTX 560 with 2GB of VRAM. Initially, the game set itself to high, and it was running a bit sluggishly—not to the point of being unplayable, but when I lowered it to medium, it smoothed out. I'm not sure if I'm just fortunate regarding game issues, but it seems most negative reviews come from some really entitled individuals.

+RPG leveling +wide variety of ship types +physics-based movement for both ships and projectiles/missiles +easy-to-learn resource management +dark humor -grind intensive (if underutilizing the civilian station types) -subpar AI teammates -low variety of equipment types -low variety of leveling skills (that is, no branching) Listen, this game is incredibly fun. Despite my minuses up there, there is still some variety and strategy to experience. It starts off fast and really picks up. Even though there's a low variety of equipment, it still feels like there's always another ship to unlock or skill to level up. The best way to enhance the life of this game is the mods. Fight for Universe is easily the standout, but Big Fight for Beef is also excellent.

World leaders gather to face uncertainty as more than 2,000 business and political leaders from around the globe arrive in the Swiss mountain resort of Davos for the annual World Economic Forum (WEF). For five days, they will discuss issues ranging from China's economic power to Iraq's future after this Sunday's elections. UK Prime Minister Tony Blair and South African President Thabo Mbeki are among the more than 20 government leaders attending. Unlike in previous years, protests against the WEF are expected to be muted. Anti-globalisation campaigners have called off a demonstration planned for the weekend. The Brazilian city of Porto Alegre will host the rival World Social Forum, timed to coincide with the WEF's more opulent event in Davos.

Deadline Approaches for Fiat-GM Deal

Fiat and General Motors (GM) face a midnight deadline on 1 February to resolve their disagreement over a potential takeover. This marks the point when Fiat gains the right to sell its car division to GM, as part of a 2000 alliance. GM, whose European operations are unprofitable, is unwilling to acquire the struggling Fiat unit. Talks at an impasse led to a 1.2% drop in Fiat shares on Tuesday, following a 4% rise on Monday due to payoff hopes. The U.S. firm reportedly offers $2bn (£1.06bn) to exit the deal, asserting that Fiat's decision to sell its finance arm and halve GM's stake rendered the agreement void. The 2000 deal emerged from a competition between GM and DaimlerChrysler to partner with Fiat.

Cardinal criticizes Iraq war: billions of pounds spent on conflict in Iraq and the Middle East should have been used to reduce poverty, Cardinal Cormac Murphy-O'Connor has said. The head of the Catholic Church in England and Wales made the comments on BBC Radio 4 and will reiterate his stance in his Christmas Midnight Mass. The cardinal used a Christmas message to denounce the war in Iraq as a "terrible" waste of money. He and the Archbishop of Canterbury have both spoken out about the war. Speaking on BBC Radio 4's Thought for the Day slot, he criticized the fact that "billions" have been spent on war, instead of being used to bring people "out of dire poverty and malnourishment and disease." The cardinal said 2005 should be the year for campaigning to "make poverty history.

British stars were denied major Oscars as UK celebrities failed to win acting and directing prizes. Despite three nominations, Mike Leigh's "Vera Drake" did not win the director or screenplay awards, and no prize was awarded to star Imelda Staunton. Kate Winslet also lost Best Actress to Hilary Swank, while Clive Owen and Sophie Okonedo failed to secure Best Supporting Actor awards. However, the UK's Andrea Arnold won the Short Film award for her gritty drama "Wasp." Arnold, who presented children's television shows "Number 73" and "Motormouth" in the 1980s, said it was "totally overwhelming" to win. "Wasp" tells the story of a single mother living on the breadline, surpassing films by fellow UK nominees Gary McKendry and Ashvin Kumar.

Debra Hill, a screenwriter and producer best known for her work on the '70s horror classic "Halloween," has passed away in Los Angeles at the age of 54. Hill, who had been battling cancer, co-wrote the 1978 film featuring Jamie Lee Curtis as a babysitter terrorized by a psychopath. Directed by John Carpenter, it earned over $60 million (£31.3 million) worldwide—a record for independent film at that time. Hill collaborated with Carpenter on "Escape from New York" and "The Fog." Born in New Jersey, she started as a production assistant, advancing to become an assistant director and second-unit director before teaming up with Carpenter. She was seen by many as a trailblazer for women in film, taking jobs in the '70s traditionally held by men.

Broadband fuels online expression. Fast web access is encouraging more people to express themselves online, research suggests. A quarter of broadband users in Britain regularly upload content and maintain personal sites, according to a report by UK think-tank Demos. It stated that having an always-on, fast connection is changing the way people use the internet. More than five million households in the UK have broadband, and that number is rapidly increasing. The Demos report examined the impact of broadband on people's net habits. It found that more than half of those with broadband logged onto the web before breakfast. One in five even admitted to getting up in the middle of the night to browse. More significantly, the report argues, broadband is motivating people to take a more active role online.

Yukos is heading back to U.S. courts. The Russian oil and gas company is due in a U.S. court on Thursday as it continues to fight for its survival. The firm is being broken up by Russian authorities to address a $27bn (£14bn) tax bill. Yukos filed for bankruptcy in the U.S., hoping international business law will prevent the forced sale of its key oil production unit, Yuganskneftegas. The unit was sold for $9.4bn to Rosneft after the state auction was disrupted. Yukos lawyers now argue that the auction violated U.S. bankruptcy law. The company and its main shareholders have vowed to pursue any buyer of its assets through legal means.

Voters are flocking to the blog awards site now that voting is underway for the annual Bloggies, which recognize the year's best web blogs—online spaces where people publish their thoughts. Nominations were announced on Sunday; however, traffic to the official site was so heavy that it temporarily closed due to an overwhelming number of visitors. Weblogs have been nominated in 30 categories, ranging from the top regional blog to the best-kept-secret blog. Blogs experienced a significant year, with a prominent U.S. dictionary naming "blog" the word of 2004. Technorati, a blog search engine, tracks about six million blogs and reports that more than 12,000 are added daily. According to the U.S. research think-tank Pew Internet and American Life, a new blog is created every 5.8 seconds, though less than 40% are updated at least once every two months.

The Chinese Three Gorges Project Corp is reportedly defying a government order to cease construction on one of its massive dams, according to state media. Despite directives to halt work on the Xiluodu Dam due to insufficient environmental evaluations, the builder of the Three Gorges Dam continues its activities, as reported by the Beijing News. The company might opt to pay a penalty instead of complying. It has also ignored orders to pause construction on two other projects: the Three Gorges Underground Power Plant and the Three Gorges Project Electrical Power Supply Plant. To date, only 22 of the 30 construction projects targeted by the State Environmental Protection Agency (SEPA) have adhered to the shutdown order due to a lack of required environmental impact assessments.

Manchester United reduced Chelsea's Premiership lead to nine points with a scrappy 2-0 victory over Manchester City. Wayne Rooney connected with Gary Neville's cross to the near post with a low shot, which deflected off Richard Dunne, giving United the lead. Seven minutes later, Dunne unfortunately sent a volley over David James' head into his own net. Steve McManaman wasted City's best chance, shooting wide from three yards in the first half. In the opening 45 minutes, United seemed unlikely to secure the win they needed to chase Chelsea in the title race. Their approach play appeared more labored than patient, with only one chance in the form of a Paul Scholes header over the bar.

Wales 'must learn health lessons,' the new health minister for Wales says, indicating there are lessons to learn from England in tackling waiting lists. Dr. Brian Gibbons, on his first full day in the role after Jane Hutt was sacked, acknowledged "big challenges" but insisted the "essentials" were in place. However, both Plaid Cymru and the Liberal Democrats asserted Dr. Gibbons needed to change policy. Meanwhile, Ms. Hutt defended her record, stating waiting times and lists were "only 10% of the health agenda." Dr. Gibbons, who was a GP in Blaengwynfi, in the upper Afan Valley, before becoming AM for Aberavon, noted NHS staff desired a period of consolidation after "tremendous change and reform." One of the biggest issues Ms. Hutt faced during her tenure was the length of waiting lists in Wales.

Ferguson hails Man Utd's resolve. Manchester United's Alex Ferguson praised his players' gutsy performance in the 1-0 victory at Aston Villa. "That was our hardest away game of the season, and it was a fantastic game of football, end-to-end with lots of good passing," said the Old Trafford boss. "We showed lots of character and determination; we weren't going to lose. I look at that fixture and think we've been there and won, while Arsenal and Chelsea have yet to come. Villa may have some players back when they do." Ferguson also praised senior stars Ryan Giggs and Roy Keane, who came off the bench for the injured John O'Shea. "Roy brought composure to the midfield, which we needed and no other player has got.

A documentary offering an intimate glimpse into the life of chart-topping singer George Michael will be showcased at this year's Berlin Film Festival. "A Different Story" is set to screen in the Panorama section of the festival, which runs from 10-20 February. It features the singer discussing both his career and personal life, from his days in Wham! to more recent events. Michael will attend the festival to introduce the screening on 16 February. Director Southan Morris and executive producer Andy Stephens will also be present. The 93-minute film will see Michael exploring his early days in Wham! along with his later career, including his legal battles with record label Sony and his stance against the Iraq War and American politics.

Downloads have now entered the US singles chart as digital music downloads are being included for the first time. Billboard's Hot 100 chart now incorporates data from music download sales, which were previously assigned to a separate download chart. Green Day's "Boulevard of Broken Dreams" is currently number two on Billboard's pop chart and tops its digital chart. Download sales are due to be included in the UK singles chart later this year. Digital sales in the US already contribute to Billboard's Hot Digital Sales chart. They will now be combined with physical singles sales and airplay data to form the new Hot 100 chart. The second new chart, the Pop 100, also combines airplay and digital and physical sales but confines its airplay information to US radio stations that play chart music.

Anti-spam laws have hit a self-proclaimed "spam king" hard, as he is now seeking bankruptcy protection. Scott Richter, behind OptInRealBig.com and known for sending billions of junk mail messages, said lawsuits led the company to file for Chapter 11. The company is battling several legal issues, notably against Microsoft, which seeks millions in damages. Filing for Chapter 11 aims to help resolve these legal problems while keeping operations running. Ranked as the third largest spammer globally by Spamhaus, OptInRealBig was sued in December 2003 for violating anti-spam laws. This lawsuit was initiated by Microsoft and New York Attorney General Eliot Spitzer, who accused Richter and his associates of sending billions of spam messages through 514 compromised network addresses across 35 countries.

Arnesen denies rift with Santini. Tottenham sporting director Frank Arnesen has denied that coach Jacques Santini resigned due to a clash of personalities at White Hart Lane. There had been newspaper speculation that Santini felt undermined by Arnesen's role at the club. "It is absolutely not true," Arnesen told BBC Radio Five Live. "There is only one thing that made him resign, and that is his own personal problems. He has talked to me recently and said this matter is absolutely his own." Arnesen said he was unable to shed light on the problems that caused Santini to quit after just 13 games in charge. He added: "Jacques has never gone into exactly what it was. But I trust him on that; you have to accept it. I think we should respect it.

Ireland surged past Scotland, maintaining their Six Nations Grand Slam ambitions with an impressive victory at Murrayfield. Hugo Southwell's try gave the Scots an early 8-0 lead, but scores from locks Malcolm O'Kelly and Paul O'Connell put the visitors in command by half-time. A third try from wing Denis Hickie and a third penalty from Ronan O'Gara, who kicked 13 points, extended the lead. Jon Petrie scored a second try for Scotland, but late scores from John Hayes and Gavin Duffy sealed victory. After two hard-earned away victories, Eddie O'Sullivan's side can now look forward to welcoming England to Lansdowne Road in a fortnight. Scotland will endeavor to give their coach, Matt Williams, a first Six Nations victory when Italy comes to Edinburgh but they again struggled to turn pressure into points.

The focus of the election battle will be Britain's economic future, according to Chancellor Gordon Brown, who stated this would be at the heart of Labour's campaign. After the cabinet's final meeting at No. 10 before the anticipated election announcement, he expressed confidence that voters would acknowledge Labour's role in providing stability and growth, pledging to continue this trajectory. Meanwhile, the Tories presented their strategies to address "yob culture," and the Lib Dems shared further details on their plans to replace council tax. Earlier, the Archbishop of Canterbury wrote to all three parties, urging them not to exploit people's fears during the election. In his open letter, he cautioned against turning the election into a contest of who can most effectively incite fear about terrorism, asylum, and crime.

Brizzel to Compete in AAA's in Sheffield Ballymena sprinter Paul Brizzel will be among eight of Ireland's European indoor hopefuls participating in this weekend's AAA's championships. U.S.-based Alistair Cragg and Mark Carroll are the only Irish athletes selected so far for the Europeans who will not compete in Sheffield. Brizzel will defend his 200m title in the British trials. In-form James McIlroy aims to secure his spot in the British team for Madrid by winning the 800m title. McIlroy has been in tremendous form on the European circuit in recent weeks. He is one of the fastest 800m runners in the world this winter and seems assured of a place in Madrid. Corkman Mark Carroll confirmed midweek that he would join Cragg in the European championships. Carroll is currently ranked number three in the world 3000m ranking, with Cragg holding the top spot.

Robinson seeks dual code success. England rugby union captain Jason Robinson aims for dual code success over Australia on Saturday. Robinson, a former rugby league international before switching codes in 2000, leads England against Australia at Twickenham at 1430 GMT. At 1815 GMT, Great Britain's rugby league team competes against Australia in the final of the Tri-Nations tournament. "Beating the Aussies in both games would be a massive achievement, especially for league," said Robinson. England has the chance to secure their third autumn international victory after wins over Canada and South Africa, as well as avenge June's 51-15 defeat by the Wallabies. Meanwhile, Great Britain could end 34 years of failure against Australia with victory at Elland Road.

Warning over tsunami aid website: Internet users are being cautioned to avoid a scam website purporting to collect money on behalf of tsunami victims. The site appears legitimate because it uses an old version of the official Disasters Emergency Committee webpage. However, the DEC has no affiliation with the fraudulent site and reports that it has alerted the police. This website is merely the latest in a series of scams exploiting the goodwill generated by the tsunami disaster. A link to the fake website is included in a spam email currently circulating. The email's subject line reads "urgent tsunami earthquake appeal," and its content contains the poor grammar and spelling typical of many phishing attempts.

Iraq is set to invite bids for two telephone licenses, aiming for significant nationwide coverage improvements over the next decade. Bids are invited from local, Arab, and international companies, announced Iraq's Ministry of Communications. The selected company will partner with the Iraqi Telecommunications and Post Company (ITPC) to install and operate a fixed phone network, offering voice, fax, and internet services. The ministry expressed its goal to raise Iraq's "very low telephone service penetration rate from about 4.5% today to about 25% within 10 years." It also aims to develop a "highly visible and dynamic telecommunications sector." Details of the bidding and tender process will be available on the ministry's website on 9 February. Additionally, a roadshow for investors is planned in Amman, Jordan.

More women are turning to net security as older individuals and women increasingly take charge of protecting home computers against malicious internet attacks, according to a two-year study. The number of women purchasing programs to safeguard PCs from viruses, spam, and spyware attacks increased by 11.2% each year from 2002 to 2004. The study, conducted for the net security firm Preventon, shows that security messages are reaching a diverse group of surfers. It is believed that 40% of those purchasing home net security programs are retired individuals. In the past three years, that number has increased by an average of 13.2%. Notably, more retired women (53%) are buying security software than retired men. The research reflects the changing stereotypes and demographics of web users, as well as growing awareness of the risks posed by high-speed broadband internet connections.

Podcasts signify the rise of DIY radio. An Apple iPod or other digital music players can hold up to 10,000 songs, leaving a lot of space to fill. Increasingly, iPod owners are filling that space with audio content from a diverse range of producers. This phenomenon, known as "podcasting," is championed by former MTV host and VJ Adam Curry. Named after the Apple iPod, podcasting doesn’t require one for creation or listening. A podcast is essentially an internet-based radio show, typically produced in the comfort of one's home. Creators only need a microphone, a PC, and some editing software. After recording, they upload their shows to the internet, allowing others to download and listen for free.

Andrea Levy, an Orange Prize winner, has seen her book "Small Island" win the Whitbread Novel of the Year award. She is now the favorite to win the overall prize after surpassing Booker winner Alan Hollinghurst's "The Line of Beauty." Geraldine McCaughrean has received the children's fiction award for the third time for "Not the End of the World." All category winners advance to compete for the Whitbread Book of the Year title, which awards a £25,000 prize. A panel of judges, including Sir Trevor McDonald, actor Hugh Grant, and writer Joanne Harris, will convene on 25 January to decide the overall winner, with the announcement made later that evening. Bookmaker William Hill has placed Levy's London-based novel as the 6/4 favorite to win.

Yukos seeks court action on the sale. Yukos will return to a U.S. court on Wednesday to seek sanctions against Baikal Finance Group, the little-known firm which has bought its main asset. Yukos has said it will sue Baikal and others involved in the sale of Yuganskneftegas for $20 billion in damages. Yukos' U.S. lawyers will attempt to have Baikal's assets frozen after the Russian government ignored a U.S. court order last week blocking the sale. Baikal's background and its motives for buying the unit remain unclear. Russian newspapers have claimed that Baikal—which bought the Yuganskneftegas production unit for $9.4 billion (261 billion roubles, £4.8 billion) on Sunday at a state-provoked auction—has strong links with Surgutneftegas, Russia's fourth-biggest oil producer.

Hearts secured their Scottish Cup quarter-final tie against Livingston with two goals in the first 10 minutes. Lee Miller scored within the opening 60 seconds, heading over Colin Meldrum and into the net from a Jamie McAllister free kick. McAllister scored the second by connecting with Saul Mikoliunas' cross at the back post, putting the game beyond the visitors. Craig Easton headed in a controversial goal after an hour, but Hearts held firm. The opening goal came after Gus Bahoken fouled Miller 35 yards from goal, allowing McAllister to deliver a free kick into the Livi box. Miller leapt over the static visiting defense to loop his header from 10 yards over Meldrum. Just 10 minutes into the game, the home side doubled their lead. Mikoliunas sprinted down the right, crossing to the back post where McAllister raced in to head past Meldrum.

Sun Microsystems has launched a pay-as-you-go service allowing customers to rent computing power by the hour. Sun Grid costs users $1 (53p) for an hour's worth of processing and storage power on systems maintained by Sun. Grid computing is the latest concept in a company that believes computing capacity is as important a commodity as hardware and software. Sun likens grid computing to the development of electricity. The system could mature in the same way utilities like electricity and water have developed, said Sun's Chief Operating Officer Jonathan Schwartz. "Why build your own grid when you can use ours for a buck an hour?" he asked during a webcast launching Sun's quarterly network computing event in California.

Jamieson issues warning to bigots: Scotland's justice minister has warned bigoted soccer fans that she intends to impact them "where it hurts most" by banning them from matches. Cathy Jamieson stated that exclusion orders are among the measures being considered in the Scottish Executive's campaign against sectarianism. She commended Celtic and Rangers for their efforts in addressing the issue. However, the minister emphasized that stopping sectarian abuse linked with Old Firm matches is a key focus. Ms. Jamieson was speaking before the Scottish Cup third-round clash between the Glasgow clubs at Parkhead on Sunday. The sectarianism long associated with sections of the support from both clubs has become a significant target for the Executive. Last week, Ms. Jamieson and First Minister Jack McConnell met supporters' representatives from both clubs to discuss the matter.

UK debut for Kevin Spacey movie: Hollywood stars Kevin Spacey and Kate Bosworth attended the British premiere of the new film, Beyond the Sea, in London's Leicester Square on Thursday. Spacey, 45, wrote, directed, and starred in the film, inspired by the life of 1950s crooner Bobby Darin. "This is my tribute to someone I think was a remarkable talent," said Spacey, who, as Darin, sings all 18 songs on the film's soundtrack. Bosworth, 21, plays Darin's wife, real-life Hollywood actress Sandra Dee. "I knew absolutely nothing about Bobby Darin before this film, but now I'm a huge fan," said Bosworth, who attended the premiere with British boyfriend Orlando Bloom.

Leeds vs. Saracens (Fri) Headingley Friday, 25 February, 2000 GMT: The Tykes have brought in Newcastle prop Ed Kalman and Tom McGee from the Borders on loan, while fly-half Craig McMullen has joined from Narbonne. Raphael Ibanez is named at hooker for Saracens in one of four changes. Simon Raiwalui and Ben Russell are also selected in the pack, while Kevin Sorrell comes in at outside centre. Friday's game at Headingley got the go-ahead after passing an early pitch inspection. Leeds: Balshaw; Rees, Christophers, Bell, Doherty; McMullen, Dickens; McGee, Rawlinson, Gerber; Murphy, Palmer (capt), Morgan, Parks, Popham. Replacements: Kalman, Regan, Hyde, Rigney, McMillan, Rock, Vickerman.

Home phones face an uncertain future; the fixed line phone in your home could soon become an endangered species. Research by handset maker Nokia indicates that more people are using their mobile phones for every call. According to the study, over 45 million people in the UK, Germany, US, and South Korea now exclusively use mobiles. It revealed that while fixed line phones are kept for lower call charges, most respondents believe the future is definitely mobile. The Nokia-sponsored research highlighted that mobiles and fixed phones serve different purposes. Home phones are used for longer calls, whereas mobile conversations tend to be shorter, between mobiles and friends. In the UK, 69% of those surveyed said they preferred using their fixed phone because it remains cheaper than a mobile.

MPs Tout Lords Replacement Plan

A group of MPs is raising pressure on Tony Blair regarding House of Lords reform by publishing a detailed blueprint for change. The cross-party group has unveiled a draft bill proposing a smaller second chamber, with 70% of members elected. MPs and peers have failed to agree on reform since 1999 when 600 hereditary peers lost their seats. The group argues they can gain support for removing the last 92 hereditary peers. The government postponed plans to remove the remaining hereditary peers due to anticipated opposition in the Lords. Tony Blair has emphasized the need for consensus on reforms. There are suggestions that Labour's manifesto will include proposals for altering at least the powers of the Lords.

Disappointed Scott in solid start. Allan Scott is confident of winning a medal at next week's European Indoor Championships after a solid debut on the international circuit. The 22-year-old Scot finished fourth in the 60m hurdles at the José M. Cagigal Memorial meeting in Madrid. "It was definitely a learning curve, and I certainly haven't ruled out challenging for a medal next week," said the East Kilbride athlete. The race was won by Felipe Vivancos, who equaled the Spanish record. Sweden's Robert Kronberg was second, with Haiti's Dudley Dorival in third. Scott was slightly disappointed with his run in the final. He won his heat in 7.64 secs but ran 0.04 secs slower in his first IAAF Indoor Grand Prix circuit final.

A woman from the U.S. is suing Hewlett-Packard (HP), alleging that its printer ink cartridges are programmed to expire after a certain date. The unnamed Georgia woman claims a chip inside the cartridge instructs the printer to indicate it needs refilling, even if it does not. The lawsuit aims to represent anyone in the U.S. who has purchased an HP inkjet printer since February 2001. HP, the world's largest printer company, declined to comment. HP ink cartridges feature chip technology to detect low ink levels and notify the user. However, the suit alleges that these chips also disable the cartridges at a predetermined date, regardless of ink levels.

Virgin Radio offers 3G broadcast. UK broadcaster Virgin Radio says it will become the first station in the world to offer radio via 3G mobiles. The station, in partnership with technology firm Sydus, will broadcast on selected 2G and high-speed 3G networks. Later this year, listeners will be able to download software from the Virgin website to enable the service. James Cridland, head of new media at Virgin Radio, said, "It places radio at the heart of the 3G revolution." Virgin Radio will be the first station made available, followed by two digital stations: Virgin Radio Classic Rock and Virgin Radio Groove. Mr. Cridland said, "This application will enable anyone, anywhere to listen to Virgin Radio simply with the phone in their pocket.

Roxy Music will perform at June's Isle of Wight Music Festival, along with Morrissey, Supergrass, and Idlewild. REM has already been confirmed as headliners for the three-day event, which takes place from 10-12 June. Original band members Bryan Ferry, Phil Manzerana, Andy Mackay, and Paul Thompson will take to the stage on Saturday night. The band is also working in the studio on new material, their first since the 1982 album Avalon. Roxy Music was formed in 1971 by Ferry, Mackay, and Brian Eno, with Manzanera joining the following year. Their first hit was 1972's "Virginia Plain," with other hits including "Street Life," "Love Is the Drug," and the 1981 John Lennon cover, "Jealous Guy.

Captains lining up for aid match: Ireland's Brian O'Driscoll is one of four Six Nations captains included in the Northern Hemisphere squad for the IRB Rugby Aid match on 5 March. France's Fabien Pelous, Gordon Bullock of Scotland, and Italy's Marco Bortolami are also part of the Northern side. Sir Clive Woodward will coach against Rod Macqueen's Southern Hemisphere team in a tsunami fundraising match at Twickenham. "I'm looking forward to working with such outstanding players," he said. It will be a chance for Woodward to assess his options before unveiling his British and Irish Lions touring party, who will visit New Zealand in the summer. "The game promises to be a great spectacle," he added.

The comedy "Sideways" dominated this year's Independent Spirit Awards, winning all six awards for which it was nominated. It was named Best Film, with Alexander Payne winning Best Director and Best Screenplay, along with writing partner Jim Taylor. It also won acting awards for stars Paul Giamatti, Thomas Haden Church, and Virginia Madsen. "Sideways" is expected to perform well at Sunday's Oscars, with five nominations. The awards, now in their 20th year, are given to films made outside the traditional studio system and are traditionally held the day before the Oscars. Other winners included Catalina Sandino Moreno, who took Best Actress for her role as a drug smuggler in the Colombian drama "Maria Full of Grace." Moreno is also nominated for Best Actress at the Oscars. The Best First Screenplay award went to Joshua Marston for "Maria Full of Grace.

Prince was crowned the 'top music earner' in 2004, surpassing pop stars like Madonna and Elton John, according to Rolling Stone magazine's annual list. The singer made $56.5 million (£30.4 million) from concerts, albums, and publishing sales with his Musicology tour and album. Madonna took second place, earning $54.9 million (£29.5 million) from her global Re-Invention Tour. Simon and Garfunkel ranked 10th, with their comeback tour bringing in $24.9 million (£13.4 million) last year. "Prince returned to center stage after a decade in the commercial wilderness," the magazine stated. His 2004 tour grossed $90.3 million (£48.5 million) in ticket sales, and he sold 1.9 million copies of his latest album, Musicology.

Walmart Fights Back at Accusers

Two major U.S. companies have launched advertising campaigns to "set the record straight" about their products and corporate behavior. The world's largest retailer, Walmart, placed over 100 full-page ads in national newspapers. The group aims to counter criticism regarding its pay deals, benefits package, and promotion strategy. Meanwhile, pharmaceutical company Eli Lilly is planning a campaign against "false" claims about its product Prozac. Walmart initiated the effort with ads in newspapers like The Wall Street Journal, featuring an open letter from company President Lee Scott stating it was time for the public to hear the "unfiltered truth." "There are lots of 'urban legends' going around these days about Walmart, but facts are facts.

The Tories unveiled plans for local communities to elect their own police commissioners. Party leader Michael Howard stated this new role would replace "inconspicuous" police authorities but not supersede the role of a chief constable. The Liberal Democrats warned that the plan might allow extreme groups to influence policing, while Labour criticized the Conservatives' "extravagant" promises. The chairman of the Police Federation of England and Wales emphasized the importance of maintaining operational independence. Jan Berry remarked, "It is a service, not a political football to be kicked around every election." She cautioned that these plans could enable those with extreme political views to dictate on-the-ground actions.

At a glance: Tory health checks - The UK's opposition Conservatives have unveiled plans to introduce health checks for immigrants if they win the general election. Here's a guide to the plan: People coming to live and work in Britain from outside the EU who plan to stay six months or more and are from countries with high TB incidence would require a chest X-ray and further tests if necessary. All individuals from outside the European Union wishing to stay a year or more will be required to undergo a full medical screening for tuberculosis, hepatitis B, and HIV. A positive TB test would automatically result in visa applications being denied. Other health conditions would be addressed on a case-by-case basis.

Doves have soared to the top of the UK album charts, as Manchester rock band Doves claim the number one spot with their new release, "Some Cities."
