The trio replace the flamboyant US act Scissor Sisters at the summit. This album follows the single "Black and White Town," which reached number six. R&B star Nelly has secured the new number one single with "Over and Over," featuring Tim McGraw. Girls Aloud, Akon, and Kaiser Chiefs have debuted new singles in the top ten, as do Futureheads and Usher. The latest Elvis Presley re-release, "(Marie's the Name) His Latest Flame," entered the chart at number three, just ahead of Girls Aloud's "Wake Me Up." Hip-hop artist Akon's "Locked Up" is at number five, while Leeds band Kaiser Chiefs have their second chart hit at number six with "Oh My God.

Davies favors Gloucester future Wales hooker Mefin Davies is likely to stay with the English side Gloucester despite reported interest from the Neath-Swansea Ospreys. BBC Wales understands the Ospreys are interested in the 32-year-old, but he would prefer to remain where he is. Davies, one of the stars of Saturday's RBS Six Nations win over England, is only on a year contract at Kingsholm. However, the hooker has proven his worth to the Zurich Premiership side and is likely to secure a new deal next season. The summer demise of the Celtic Warriors region left Davies in the cold and forced him to take a semi-professional contract with Neath RFC. Although he got match time with the Ospreys at the request of the Wales management, he admitted before his move to Gloucester that he was angry with the way he was treated.

Cabinet anger at Brown cash raid: Ministers are unhappy about plans to use Whitehall funds to keep council tax bills down, local government minister Nick Raynsford has acknowledged. Gordon Brown reallocated £512 million from central to local government budgets in his pre-budget report on Thursday. Raynsford said he had some "pretty frank discussions" with ministers over the plans. However, he emphasized that local governments must deliver quality services without significant council tax increases. The central government funds are part of a £1 billion package to help local authorities in England keep next year's council tax rises below 5%, in what is likely to be an election year. Raynsford said nearly all central government departments had an interest in well-run local authorities.

Israeli club looks to Africa with four African players, including Zimbabwean goalkeeper Energy Murambadoro, all set to play for Israeli club Hapoel Bnei Sakhnin in the UEFA Cup. Bnei Sakhnin is the first Arab side to play in European competition and will face English Premier League team Newcastle United in the first round. Warriors' goalkeeper Murambadoro gained recognition at the African Nations Cup finals in Tunisia, helping Bnei Sakhnin defeat Albania's Partizani Tirana 6-1 in the previous round. Murambadoro recently moved to Israel after a brief stint with South African club Hellenic. The club won the Israeli Cup final last season and is based in Sakhnin, near Haifa. They have a strong ethic and are well-known promoters of peace and cooperation within Israel.

New drink limit 'would cut toll' more lives than previously thought could be saved by reducing drink-drive limits by a third, a report states. University College London research claims cutting the limit from 80mg of alcohol per 100ml of blood to 50mg would save 65 lives annually. The findings are being published by the Parliamentary Advisory Council for Transport Safety as MPs are due to vote on the government's road safety bill. The bill includes changes to speeding fines but not to the drink-drive limit. The research, conducted by transport expert Professor Richard Allsop, says reducing the limit would also result in 230 fewer serious injuries on the UK’s roads compared with 2003. He estimates that this would save the country £119m annually. A previous estimate, contained in a 1998 Department of Transport document, suggested such a move could save 50 lives annually.

This paper presents a millimeter-scale CMOS 64×64 single charged particle radiation detector system for external beam cancer radiotherapy. A 1×1 μm² diode measures energy deposition by a single charged particle in the depletion region, and the array design provides a large detection area of 512×512 μm². Instead of sensing the voltage drop caused by radiation, this system measures the pulse width, or the time for the voltage to return to its baseline. This eliminates the need for power-hungry, large analog-to-digital converters. A prototype ASIC is fabricated in TSMC 65 nm LP CMOS process and consumes an average static power of 0.535 mW under a 1.2 V analog and digital power supply. The functionality of the entire system is successfully verified in a clinical 67.5 MeV proton beam setting.

Routing controllability of autonomous vehicles (AVs) has been shown to reduce the impact of selfish routing on network efficiency. However, the assumption that AVs would readily submit to external control by a central agency is unrealistic. In this paper, we propose a joint routing and pricing control scheme designed to incentivize AVs to opt for centrally controlled system-optimal routing by offering toll savings, while those seeking user equilibrium (UE) or human-driven vehicles (HVs) incur congestion charges. The problem is formulated as a bi-level optimization: dynamic tolls are optimized in the upper level, while the lower level encompasses a mixed equilibrium simulation-based dynamic traffic assignment model for a mixed fleet of AVs and HVs.

Optomechanics and electromechanics have enabled macroscopic mechanical oscillators to achieve quantum ground states, quadrature squeezed states, and entangled states of motion. This advancement has not only allowed for larger, tangible objects to exhibit quantum behavior but also sparked ideas of employing mechanical oscillators in quantum information processing, communication, and precision force sensing beyond the standard quantum limit. However, the linear interaction between motion and light or electricity limits access to a wider range of quantum states of motion, such as cat states or energy squeezed states. Early optomechanical proposals highlighted the potential to overcome this limitation by generating strong quadratic coupling between motion and light. Although experimental demonstrations of quadratically coupled optomechanical systems exist, they have not yet achieved nonclassical states of motion.

Online reviews provide product evaluations for customers, aiding in decision-making. Unfortunately, these evaluations can be manipulated through fake reviews by professional spammers who continually adapt to detection methods with increasingly subtle strategies. Spamming is challenging to capture because tactics evolve rapidly, vary among spammers and products, and often remain unknown. Furthermore, existing detectors prioritize detection accuracy, which doesn't necessarily align with fostering trustworthy evaluations. To address these issues, we propose a minimax game where spammers and detectors compete based on practical goals beyond mere accuracy. The Nash equilibria reached in this game result in stable detectors that remain effective regardless of the spammers' varied detection tactics.

We developed single-shot shaped pulses for ultra high fidelity (uh-fidelity) population transfer in a 3-level quantum system with a lambda configuration. To ensure high fidelity, we apply the Lewis-Riesenfeld (l-r) method to derive a family of solutions leading to an exact transfer, where the solutions adhere to a single dynamical mode of the l-r invariant. Within this family, we identify a tracking solution with a single parameter to simultaneously control the fidelity of the transfer, the population of the excited state, and robustness. We define robustness as the minimum percentile deviation on the pulse areas at which infidelity exceeds $10^{-4}$. The robustness of our shaped pulses surpasses that of Gaussian and adiabatically-optimized pulses for moderate pulse areas.

In this paper, we analyze the landscape of the population negative log-likelihood function of Gaussian mixture models with a varying number of components. Due to nonconvexity, multiple local minima exist that are not globally optimal, even when the mixture is well-separated. We demonstrate that all local minima have a structural form that partially identifies the component centers of the true mixture. Specifically, each local minimum involves fitting multiple Gaussians to a single true component and fitting a single Gaussian to multiple true components without overlap. Our findings apply when the true mixture components satisfy a specific separation condition and remain valid whether the number of components is over- or under-specified. For Gaussian mixtures with three components, we obtain sharper results concerning the scaling with the separation between the components.

We consider the connection between two constructions of the mirror partner for the Calabi-Yau orbifold. This orbifold is defined as a quotient by a suitable subgroup \( g \) of the phase symmetries of the hypersurface \( x_m \) in the weighted projective space, cut out by a quasi-homogeneous polynomial \( w_m \). The first, Berglund-Hübsch-Krawitz (BHK) construction, uses another weighted projective space and the quotient of a new hypersurface \( x_{m^t} \) inside it by a dual group \( g^t \). In the second, Batyrev construction, the mirror partner is constructed as a hypersurface in the toric variety defined by the reflexive polytope dual to the original. We provide simple evidence of these constructions' equivalence.

In this work, a generalization of the study of the human gait was developed from existing models in the literature, such as those of Keller and Kockshenev. In this hybrid model, a strategy of metabolic energy minimization is combined in a race process, with a non-linear description of the movement of the mass center's libration, aiming to replicate the walk-run transition behavior. The results of the experimental data, for different speed regimes, suggest that the perimeter of the trajectory of the mass center is a relevant factor in quantifying this dynamic. An experimental procedure was implemented in collaboration with the research group in biomedical engineering, basic sciences, and laboratories of Manuela Beltrán University in Bogotá, Colombia.

We present a new mixed variable symplectic (MVS) integrator for planetary systems that fully resolves close encounters. This method employs time regularization, maintaining the stability properties of symplectic integrators while reducing the effective step size during planetary encounters. Utilizing a high-order MVS scheme allows for integration with large time steps away from close encounters. Our algorithm resolves almost exact collisions (e.g., with a mutual separation of a fraction of the physical radius) using the same time step as in weakly perturbed problems, such as the solar system. We demonstrate the long-term behavior in systems of six super-Earths experiencing strong scattering over 50 kyr. We compare our approach to hybrid methods like Mercury, showing that for an equivalent cost, we achieve much better energy conservation.

Entanglement is a key resource for quantum information processing. A widely used tool for detecting entanglement is the entanglement witness, where the measurement of the witness operator is guaranteed to be positive for all separable states and can be negative for certain entangled states. Due to the exponentially increasing Hilbert-space dimension with respect to the system size, constructing an efficient entanglement witness for general multipartite entangled states is challenging. For $n$-partite Greenberger-Horne-Zeilinger (GHZ)-like states, the most robust witness scheme requires $n+1$ local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/2$ white noise. In comparison, the most efficient witness for GHZ-like states needs only two local measurement settings and can tolerate up to $1/3$ white noise.

Within general relativity, the unique stationary solution of an isolated black hole is the Kerr spacetime, characterized by a distinct multipolar structure dependent solely on its mass and spin. We develop a comprehensive method to extract the multipole moments of arbitrary stationary spacetimes and apply it to a vast range of horizonless microstate geometries. These geometries can disrupt the axial and equatorial symmetry of the Kerr metric and possess a significantly richer multipolar structure, offering a pathway to constrain fuzzball models phenomenologically. We find numerical evidence that all multipole moments are generally larger (in absolute value) than those of a Kerr black hole with the same mass and spin. Current measurements of the quadrupole moment of black-hole candidates offer only slight constraints on fuzzballs, whereas future gravitational-wave detections of extreme mass-ratio inspirals with the space mission LISA will enhance these bounds significantly.

Reasoning about graphs evolving over time is a challenging concept in many domains, including bioinformatics, physics, and social networks. We consider a common case where edges are short-term interactions (e.g., messaging) or long-term structural connections (e.g., friendship). Long-term edges are often specified by humans and can be expensive and suboptimal for downstream tasks. We propose a model based on temporal point processes and variational autoencoders that learns to infer temporal attention between nodes by observing node communication. As temporal attention drives between-node feature propagation, using node interaction dynamics to learn this key component provides more flexibility while avoiding issues associated with human-specified edges.

Observations of thermally driven transverse vibration of a photonic crystal waveguide (PCW) are reported. The PCW consists of two parallel nanobeams with a 240 nm vacuum gap between them. Models are developed and validated for the transduction of beam motion to phase and amplitude modulation of a weak optical probe propagating in a guided mode (GM) of the PCW for probe frequencies far from and near the dielectric band edge. Since our PCW is designed for near-field atom trapping, this research provides a foundation for evaluating potential detrimental effects of thermal motion on optical atomic traps near the PCW surfaces. Long-term goals include achieving strong atom-mediated links between individual phonons of vibration and single photons in the GMs of the PCW, enabling opto-mechanics at the quantum level with atoms, photons, and phonons.

We establish natural splittings for the values of global Mackey functors at orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups. In particular, the restriction homomorphisms between the orthogonal, unitary, and symplectic groups of adjacent dimensions are naturally split epimorphisms. Interest in these splittings arises from equivariant stable homotopy theory, where the equivariant stable homotopy groups of every global spectrum form a global Mackey functor. These splittings imply that certain long exact homotopy group sequences decompose into short exact sequences. For the real and complex global Thom spectra $\mathbf{mo}$ and $\mathbf{mu}$, the splittings signify the regularity of various Euler classes related to the tautological representations of $o(n)$ and $u(n)$.

Baryonic feedback effects suppress the weak lensing angular power spectrum on small scales. The uncertain shape and amplitude of this suppression is a significant source of uncertainties for upcoming cosmological weak lensing surveys like Euclid or LSST. In this first paper of a two-part series, we use simulations to create a Euclid-like tomographic mock data-set for the cosmic shear power spectrum and the corresponding covariance matrix, both adjusted for baryonic effects using the baryonification method of Schneider et al. (2019). Additionally, we develop an emulator to obtain rapid predictions of baryonic power suppression, enabling a likelihood inference analysis for a standard $\lambda$CDM cosmology with both cosmological and astrophysical parameters.

Spontaneous conversations in real-world settings, such as those found in child-centered recordings, present some of the most challenging audio files to process. Nevertheless, developing speech processing models that handle this wide variety of conditions is particularly beneficial for language acquisition studies. Researchers focus on the quantity and quality of speech that children hear and produce, as well as on early diagnosis and remediation effects. In this paper, we present our approach to creating an open-source neural network to classify audio segments into vocalizations produced by the child wearing the recording device, vocalizations produced by other children, adult male speech, and adult female speech. We have gathered diverse child-centered corpora totaling 260 hours of recordings in 10 languages.

Density-based clustering relies on linking groups to specific features of the probability distribution underlying the data. Reference to a true, yet unknown, population structure frames the clustering problem in a standard inferential setting, where ideal population clustering is defined as the partition induced by the true density function. The nonparametric formulation of this approach, known as modal clustering, associates groups with the domains of attraction of the density modes. Operationally, a nonparametric density estimate is required, and selecting the correct amount of smoothing, which governs the density shape and potentially the modal structure, is crucial to identifying the final partition. In this work, we address density estimation for modal clustering from an asymptotic perspective.

The tails of diboson production at the LHC are sensitive to the interference between the Standard Model and higher-dimension operators parameterizing the effects of heavy new physics. However, helicity selection rules for the diboson scattering amplitudes create an obstruction to the naive interference contributions of dimension-six operators, causing the leading contribution to the total diboson rate correction to cancel. In this case, accurately measuring the azimuthal decay angles "resurrects" the interference, reclaiming sensitivity to the "non-interfering" operators. We explore these signatures in detail and find that the EFT uncertainties associated with higher-dimensional operators are uniquely well-suppressed by constructing an asymmetry variable generated solely by these non-interfering operators, relegating the effects of interfering operators to the same status as statistical errors in this observable.

Causal inference from observational data is a key goal in many health and social science studies. However, academic statistics has often treated such analyses with skepticism. The concept of "data science" presents a historic opportunity to redefine data analysis, naturally incorporating causal inference from observational data. As others have organized, we classify the scientific contributions of data science into three categories: description, prediction, and counterfactual prediction (including causal inference). Clearly classifying data science tasks is essential for discussing the data, assumptions, and analytics needed to accomplish each task. We contend that not adequately describing the role of subject-matter expert knowledge in data analysis leads to widespread misunderstandings about data science.

The weak gravity conjecture (WGC) demands the existence of superextremal particles in any consistent quantum theory of gravity. The standard lore is that these particles are introduced to ensure that extremal black holes are either unstable or marginally stable, but it is not clear what is wrong if this doesn't happen. This note shows that, for a generic Einstein quantum theory of gravity in AdS, the exact stability of extremal black branes conflicts with rigorously proven quantum information theorems about entanglement entropy. Avoiding the contradiction leads to a nonperturbative version of the WGC, which reduces to the usual statement at weak coupling. The argument is general and does not rely on either supersymmetry or a particular UV completion, assuming only the validity of Einsteinian gravity, effective field theory, and holography.

Understanding how strongly correlated two-dimensional (2D) systems can produce unconventional superconductivity with high critical temperatures is a major unsolved issue in condensed matter physics. Ultracold 2D Fermi gases have surfaced as clean and controllable model systems to explore the interplay of strong correlations and reduced dimensionality, yet direct evidence of superfluidity in these systems has been absent. Here, we demonstrate superfluidity in an ultracold 2D Fermi gas by moving a periodic potential through the system and observing no dissipation below a critical velocity \(v_{\text{c}}\). We measure \(v_{\text{c}}\) as a function of interaction strength and find a maximum in the crossover regime between bosonic and fermionic superfluidity. Our measurement establishes ultracold Fermi gases as powerful tools for studying the effects of reduced dimensionality on strongly correlated superfluids.

An ordinary differential equation (ODE) is a mathematical model used in various fields such as climatology, bioinformatics, and chemical engineering due to its intuitive appeal for modeling. Despite its widespread application, the frequent lack of analytic solutions makes estimating ODE parameters challenging, especially for models with many variables and parameters. This paper introduces a Bayesian ODE parameter estimation algorithm that is both fast and accurate, even for complex models. The method approximates an ODE model using a state-space model based on numeric solver equations, enabling swift estimation by bypassing the need for full numerical solution computations in the likelihood. The posterior is obtained through a variational Bayes method, specifically the approximate Riemannian conjugate gradient method (Honkela et al.).

We examine the transport properties and superconducting proximity effect in nsn junctions created by a time-reversal symmetry broken Weyl semimetal (WSM) adjacent to an $s$-wave superconductor. The differential conductance and induced pairing amplitudes are significantly influenced by the angle between the junction direction in real space and the axis separating the Weyl nodes in momentum space. We investigate the impact of a chiral chemical potential, i.e., the electron population imbalance between Weyl nodes of opposite chirality, on the junction's transport characteristics. Notably, we detect a net spin polarization of Cooper pairs generated via Andreev reflection in the two WSM regions. This spin polarization is opposite in the two WSM regions and highly sensitive to the chirality imbalance and excitation energy.

Metal ion implantation into ceramics is a highly effective and controllable technique for tailoring the surface electrical conductivity of ceramic pieces, applied in various contexts. This method importantly grades the voltage drop across high-voltage insulators, enhancing the maximum voltage they can withstand without surface flashover. A concern is the long-term stability of implantation-induced conductivity, especially if the implanted metal oxidizes easily. We examined the long-term behavior of surface conductivity in titanium-implanted alumina. Results show an initial conductivity drop of up to 40% within the first few weeks post-implantation, followed by a very slow decrease of about 10% over the subsequent year.

We present a new Skyrme-like conserved current in the effective theory of pions and vector mesons, inspired by the concept of hidden local symmetry. The associated charge matches the skyrmion charge for any smooth configuration. Furthermore, there are singular configurations identifiable as n_f=1 baryons charged under the new symmetry. In this context, the vector mesons act as the Chern-Simons vector fields residing on the quantum Hall droplet that constitutes the n_f=1 baryon. We propose this current as the accurate effective expression for the baryon current at low energies. This proposal provides a unified perspective for two types of baryons, enabling them to naturally transform into one another. Additionally, Chern-Simons dualities on the droplet can be viewed as a consequence of Seiberg-like duality between gluons and vector mesons.

Interfacial spin-orbit coupling in Josephson junctions offers a captivating way to merge anomalous Hall and Josephson physics within a single device. We theoretically explore how the blending of these effects influences superconductor/ferromagnetic insulator/superconductor junctions' transport properties. Transverse momentum-dependent skew tunneling of Cooper pairs through the spin-active ferromagnetic insulator interface generates significant transverse Hall supercurrents, which we term anomalous Josephson Hall effect currents. We extend the Furusaki-Tsukada formula, originally developed to quantify normal (tunneling) Josephson current flows, to assess the transverse current components and demonstrate that their amplitudes can be extensively modulated through the spin-orbit coupling strengths or the superconducting phase difference across the junction. As a distinct spectroscopic signature of these junctions, well-localized subgap bound states form around the interface.

Following the suggestion from the Monte Carlo experiments in Jiménez (J. of Turbul., 2020), which indicate that dipoles are as crucial to the dynamics of decaying two-dimensional turbulence as individual vortex cores, it is observed that the kinetic energy of this flow is transported by elongated streams formed by the concatenation of dipoles. Vortices separate into a group of small, fast-moving cores and another group of larger, slowly moving ones, described as 'frozen' into a slowly evolving 'crystal'. The kinematics of both groups are distinct, and only the former is self-similar. The latter accounts for most of the kinetic energy of the flow, with its vortices forming the dipoles and the streams. Mechanisms are discussed for the growth of this slow component.

Continuous-time quantum walks are an extremely useful framework for designing several quantum algorithms. Often, the running time in this framework is characterized by the quantum hitting time: the time needed for the quantum walk to find a vertex of interest with high probability. In this article, we provide improved upper bounds for the quantum hitting time, applicable to several ctqw-based quantum algorithms. Specifically, we apply our techniques to the glued-trees problem, enhancing their hitting time upper bound by a polynomial factor: from $o(n^5)$ to $o(n^2\log n)$. Furthermore, our methods also help to exponentially improve the dependence on precision for the continuous-time quantum walk-based algorithm to find a marked node on any ergodic, reversible Markov chain by Chakraborty et al.

Extreme mass ratio inspirals (EMRIs) can be classified as dry EMRIs and wet EMRIs based on their formation mechanisms. Dry (or "loss-cone") EMRIs, previously considered the main EMRI sources for the Laser Interferometer Space Antenna, are primarily produced by multi-body scattering in the nuclear star cluster and gravitational capture. In this letter, we highlight an alternative EMRI formation channel: wet EMRI formation assisted by the accretion flow around accreting galactic-center massive black holes (MBHs). In this channel, the accretion disk captures stellar-mass black holes initially on inclined orbits, subsequently driving them to migrate towards the MBH—this process significantly boosts the formation rate of EMRIs in such galaxies.

When a new user signs up on a website, we typically have no information about them: no item interactions, no user profile, and no social links with others. Despite this, we expect our recommender systems to engage users immediately, encouraging them to stay and become active. This issue is known as the new user cold-start problem, crucial for a company's growth and survival. Existing approaches to user cold-start recommendation either require additional user effort, such as conducting interviews, or utilize side information like demographics, locations, and social relations. However, users may be unwilling to participate in interviews, and side information about cold-start users is often unavailable.

Deep learning has solved many problems beyond the reach of heuristic algorithms. It has also been successfully applied in wireless communications, despite the fact that current radio systems are well-understood and optimal algorithms exist for numerous tasks. While some improvements have been achieved by learning individual parts of a receiver, a more effective approach is to jointly learn the entire receiver. This often results in a challenging nonlinear problem, for which the optimal solution is infeasible to implement. To address this, we propose a deep fully convolutional neural network, deeprx, which executes the whole receiver pipeline, from frequency domain signal stream to uncoded bits, in a 5g-compliant manner. We enhance accurate channel estimation by constructing the input of the convolutional neural network in a very specific manner using both the data and pilot symbols.

Mutation-based fuzzing typically begins with an initial set of non-crashing seed inputs (a corpus) to generate new inputs through mutation. A corpus often contains thousands of similar inputs, and this lack of diversity can result in wasted effort due to exhaustive mutation from all available seeds. To counter this, fuzzers provide distillation tools (e.g., afl-cmin) that select the smallest subset of seeds, triggering the same range of instrumentation data points as the full corpus. It is commonly believed that minimizing the number and size of seeds enhances fuzzing efficiency. We systematically explore this and present results of over 34 CPU-years of fuzzing using five distillation approaches to assess their impact in uncovering bugs in real-world software.

In this paper, we investigate multi-agent discrete-event systems with partial observation. The agents can be divided into groups wherein each has similar (isomorphic) state transition structures and can be relabeled into the same template. Based on this template, a scalable supervisor is designed, whose state size and computational cost are independent of the number of agents, even in partial observation. Regardless of how many agents are added or removed from the system, the scalable supervisor does not need to be recomputed. We extend our previous results to partial observation by proposing sufficient conditions for safety and maximal permissiveness at the template level. An example is provided to illustrate the proposed scalable supervisory synthesis.

Electric network frequency (ENF) fluctuations are a powerful tool in multimedia forensics. An efficient approach for ENF estimation is introduced using temporal windowing with the filter-bank Capon spectral estimator. A type of Gohberg-Semencul factorization of the model covariance matrix is employed due to the Toeplitz structure. Moreover, this approach utilizes, for the first time, a non-rectangular temporal window preceding spectral estimation. Krylov matrices are used for fast implementation of matrix inversions. The proposed method outperforms state-of-the-art techniques in ENF estimation, especially when a short time window of one second is utilized in power recordings. In speech recordings, the proposed approach yields high accuracy in terms of both time complexity and overall precision.

The direpack package aims to integrate a set of modern statistical dimension reduction techniques into the Python ecosystem in a single, cohesive package. The dimension reduction methods included fall into three categories: projection pursuit-based dimension reduction, sufficient dimension reduction, and robust M-estimators for dimension reduction. Additionally, regularized regression estimators based on these reduced dimension spaces are offered, ranging from classical principal component regression to sparse partial robust M regression. The package also includes various classical and robust pre-processing utilities, such as generalized spatial signs, along with dedicated plotting functionality and cross-validation utilities. Moreover, direpack is designed to be consistent with the scikit-learn API, enabling seamless integration of its estimators into learning pipelines within that framework.

Nonlinear fluorescence emission is widely used for high spatial resolution optical imaging. We studied the fluorescence anomalous saturating effect of the nitrogen vacancy defect in diamond. With high power laser excitation, fluorescence reduction was observed. This increased the nonlinearity of the fluorescence emission and altered the spatial frequency distribution of the fluorescence image. A differential excitation protocol was employed to extract high spatial frequency information. By modulating the excitation laser's power, imaging spatial resolution improved approximately 1.6 times compared to confocal microscopy. Given the simplicity of the experimental setup and data processing, we expect this method to enhance spatial resolution in sensing and biological labeling applications using defects in solids.

When random effects are correlated with sample design variables, the typical use of individual survey weights (designed to be inversely proportional to the unit survey inclusion probabilities) to form a pseudo-likelihood no longer yields asymptotically unbiased inference. We create a weight-exponentiated formulation for the random effects distribution that achieves unbiased inference for generating hyperparameters of the random effects. We compare our approach with frequentist methods that rely on numerical integration, demonstrating that only the Bayesian method succeeds in achieving both unbiased estimation regarding the sampling design distribution and consistency with respect to the population generating distribution. Our simulations and real data examples, including a survey of business establishments, display the utility of our method across various modeling formulations and sampling designs. This work serves as a capstone for recent developmental efforts combining traditional survey estimation methods with the Bayesian modeling paradigm and bridges the two rich, distinct sub-fields.

Low-symmetry 2D materials, such as res$_2$ and rese$_2$ monolayers, black phosphorus monolayers, group-IV monochalcogenide monolayers, and borophene, among others, possess more complex atomistic structures than the honeycomb lattices of graphene, hexagonal boron nitride, and transition metal dichalcogenides. The reduced symmetries of these emerging materials lead to inhomogeneous electron, optical, valley, and spin responses, as well as novel properties like ferroelasticity, ferroelectricity, magnetism, spin-wave phenomena, large nonlinear optical properties, photogalvanic effects, and superconductivity. Novel electronic topological properties, nonlinear elastic properties, and structural phase transformations can also occur due to low symmetry. The "Beyond Graphene: Low-Symmetry and Anisotropic 2D Materials" special topic was assembled to highlight recent experimental and theoretical research on these emerging materials.

The orientational dynamics in the isotropic phase of a comb-shaped nematic polymer with mesogenic and functional side groups were studied using the Kerr effect and dielectric spectroscopy. For the first time, it was discovered that in a mesogenic polymer, unlike low-molecular-weight mesogens, the relaxation of the electric birefringence in a melt above the nematic-isotropic phase transition temperature can be expressed as a sum of several exponential processes, two of which are crucial. These primary processes replace each other over a temperature range of about fifty degrees. Dielectric spectroscopy enabled the distinction of two processes of orientational relaxation: the first involves the rotation of the side mesogenic groups, and the second is linked to the motion of the main chain segments.

Deep hashing methods have demonstrated excellent retrieval accuracy and efficiency in large-scale image retrieval. Optimizing discrete hash bits is crucial in these methods. A typical approach is to use an activation function, such as $\operatorname{sigmoid}(\cdot)$ or $\operatorname{tanh}(\cdot)$, and minimize a quantization loss to approximate discrete values. However, this can result in hash bits getting stuck in the wrong saturated areas of activation functions. We refer to this as the "dead bits problem~(dbp)." Furthermore, the existing quantization loss exacerbates dbp. In this paper, we introduce a simple yet effective gradient amplifier, applied before activation functions, to mitigate dbp.

We study the phenomenology of a hypercharge-zero SU(2) triplet scalar, motivated by two-step electroweak symmetry-breaking. We consider the possibility that triplets are stable and contribute to dark matter density, or that they decay via mixing with the Standard Model Higgs boson. The former is constrained by disappearing charged track searches at the LHC and dark matter direct detection experiments, while the latter is constrained by existing multilepton collider searches. We find that a two-step electroweak phase transition involving a stable triplet with a negative quadratic term is ruled out by direct detection searches, while an unstable triplet with a mass less than $230\ \mathrm{GeV}$ is excluded at $95\%$ confidence level.

This paper demonstrates that the eccentric debris rings observed around the stars Fomalhaut and HD 202628 are narrower than anticipated in the standard eccentric planet perturbation scenario (sometimes referred to as "pericenter glow"). The conventional scenario suggests an initially circular and narrow belt of planetesimals at semi-major axis $a$, whose eccentricity increases to $e_f$ after the gas disc disperses, due to secular perturbations from an eccentric planet, resulting in a belt of width $2ae_f$. In a slight alteration of this scenario, narrower belts can form if the planetesimals are initially eccentric, possibly resulting from earlier planet perturbations during the gas-rich protoplanetary disc phase. However, primordial eccentricity could alternatively be driven by instabilities that enhance the disc's eccentricity, independent of any planets.

An electron is usually considered to have only one type of kinetic energy, but could it have more due to its spin and charge or by exciting other electrons? In one dimension (1D), the physics of interacting electrons is captured well at low energies by the Tomonaga-Luttinger-liquid (TLL) model, yet little has been observed experimentally beyond this linear regime. Here, we report on measurements of many-body modes in 1D gated wires using a tunneling spectroscopy technique. We observe two separate Fermi seas at high energies, associated with spin and charge excitations, together with the emergence of three additional 1D 'replica' modes that strengthen with decreasing wire length. The effective interaction strength in the wires is varied by changing the amount of 1D inter-subband screening by over 45%.

The assembly history experienced by the Milky Way is currently being unveiled thanks to the data provided by the Gaia mission. It is likely that the globular cluster system of our galaxy has followed a similarly intricate formation path. To constrain this formation path, we explore the link between the globular clusters and the known merging events that the Milky Way has experienced. To this end, we combined the kinematic information provided by Gaia for almost all galactic clusters, with the largest sample of cluster ages available after carefully correcting for systematic errors. To identify clusters with a common origin, we analyzed their dynamical properties, particularly in the space of integrals of motion. We find that about 40% of the clusters likely formed in situ.

Estimating the intrinsic dimension of a dataset is crucial in most dimensionality reduction techniques. This article introduces "intrinsic," an R package offering advanced likelihood-based estimators for intrinsic dimension. Specifically, the package includes the two-nn, gride, and hidalgo models. To make these estimators accessible, the package offers high-level, intuitive functions built on efficient, low-level routines. Intrinsic features models in two categories: homogeneous and heterogeneous intrinsic dimension estimators. The first category includes the two-nn and gride models, enabling inference under both frequentist and Bayesian frameworks. The second category presents hidalgo, a Bayesian mixture model, with an efficient Gibbs sampler.

Spintronic nanodevices exhibit ultrafast nonlinear dynamic and recurrence behaviors on a nanosecond scale, promising to enable spintronic reservoir computing (RC) systems. Two physical RC systems, based on a single magnetic skyrmion memristor (MSM) and 24 spin-torque nano-oscillators (STNOs), were proposed and modeled to process image classification tasks and nonlinear dynamic system prediction, respectively. Our micromagnetic simulation results on the nonlinear responses of MSM and STNOs with current pulse stimulation demonstrate that an RC system using a single MSM excels in image classification. Moreover, complex unknown nonlinear dynamic problems are effectively solved by a physical RC system consisting of 24 STNOs, confirmed in both a second-order nonlinear dynamic system and NARMA10 tasks.

Ranking algorithms are essential for online platforms, from search engines to recommender systems. This paper identifies a surprising outcome of popularity-based rankings: fewer items reporting a specific signal attract a disproportionately high share of overall traffic. This few-get-richer effect occurs in contexts with limited distinct item classes (e.g., left-leaning vs. right-leaning news) where items are ranked by popularity. We analytically show that this effect arises when users frequently click top-ranked items and have varied class preferences. Simulations explore how the effect's intensity varies with different setting and behavior assumptions. Additionally, we experimentally test our predictions with human participants. Our findings are significant for understanding misinformation spread.

Weight pruning is widely recognized as an effective method for eliminating redundancy in deep neural networks (DNN), leading to acceleration on various platforms. However, many pruning techniques involve trade-offs between model accuracy and regularity, which result in impaired inference accuracy and limited on-device acceleration. To address this, we introduce a new sparsity dimension called pattern-based sparsity, comprising pattern and connectivity sparsity, which is both highly accurate and hardware-friendly. With carefully designed patterns, the proposed pruning achieves unprecedented and consistent accuracy enhancement and improved feature extraction across different DNN structures and datasets. Our pattern-aware pruning framework also includes pattern library extraction, pattern selection, pattern and connectivity pruning, and weight training simultaneously. Our approach to pattern-based sparsity naturally integrates with compiler optimization for highly efficient DNN execution on mobile platforms.

Difference-in-differences analysis with a control group that differs considerably from a treated group is vulnerable to bias from historical events impacting the groups differently. Creating a more closely matched control group by aligning a subset of the overall control group with the treated group may reduce bias. We explore this phenomenon through simulation studies. We examine the effect of mountaintop removal mining (MRM) on mortality using a difference-in-differences analysis that utilizes the increase in MRM following the 1990 Clean Air Act amendments. For this analysis of MRM's impact on mortality, we constructed a more closely matched control group and found a 95% confidence interval that includes significant adverse effects, as well as no effect and minor beneficial effects.

When constructing models to summarize clinical data for simulations, it is good practice to evaluate the models for their capacity to reproduce the data. This can be done through visual predictive checks (VPC), which involve: (1) multiple reproductions of the original study by simulation from the model under evaluation, (2) calculating estimates of interest for each simulated study, and (3) comparing the distribution of those estimates with the estimate from the original study. This procedure is a generic method that is generally straightforward to apply. Here, we consider applying the method to time-to-event data, specifically addressing the special case when a time-varying covariate is unknown or cannot be approximated after the event time.

Novel concepts, perspectives, and challenges in measuring and controlling an open quantum system via sequential schemes are presented. We discuss how similar protocols, which rely on repeated quantum measurements and dynamical decoupling control pulses, can: (i) confine and protect quantum dynamics from decoherence in accordance with Zeno physics; (ii) analytically predict the probability that a quantum system transitions into a target quantum state through stochastic sequential measurements; (iii) optimally reconstruct the spectral density of environmental noise sources by orthogonalizing the filter functions in the frequency domain driving the designed quantum sensor. Achieving these tasks will enhance our capability to observe and manipulate open quantum systems, thus advancing quantum science and technologies.

Palms sweaty, heart racing, stomach in knots. You can't cry for help. Not only is your throat too tight to breathe, but it'd be so embarrassing. No, you aren't being stalked by a monster; you're speaking in public, a fate some deem worse than death. See, when you're dead, you feel nothing; at a podium, you feel stage fright. But at some point, we've all had to communicate in front of people, so you have to try to overcome it. To start, understand what stage fright is. Humans, social animals that we are, are wired to worry about reputation. Public speaking can threaten it. Before a speech, you fret, "What if people think I'm awful and I'm an idiot?"

I can't think of anyone who has only one interest in life, dedicating themselves to only that for their entire life. Currently, around 15 percent of American workers lack traditional full-time jobs—they're part-time, contract workers, or temps. The term "side hustle" aligns with this ethos, where people combine various roles to make a living. The word "side hustle" originated in popular African American newspapers. In the 1920s, "hustle" often referred to scams, but by the 1950s, "side hustle" included legitimate work. A side hustle differs from a second job, which is typically out of necessity.

Two twin domes, two radically opposed design cultures. One is made of thousands of steel parts, the other of a single silk thread. One is synthetic, the other organic. One is imposed on the environment, the other creates it. One is designed for nature, the other is designed by her. Michelangelo said that when he looked at raw marble, he saw a figure struggling to be free. The chisel was Michelangelo's only tool. But living things are not chiseled; they grow. In our smallest units of life, our cells, we carry all the information required for every other cell to function and replicate. Tools also have consequences. At least since the Industrial Revolution, the world of design has been dominated by the rigors of manufacturing and mass production.

Hello. My name is Simone. You know how people suggest that if you get nervous onstage, you should picture the audience naked? It's supposed to make you feel better. But I was thinking—imagining all of you naked in 2018 feels kind of weird and inappropriate. We're working hard to move past ideas like that, so we need a new method for handling stage nerves. I realized what I'd really like is to look at you as much as you look at me—just to even things out. If I had more eyeballs, we'd all be more comfortable, right?

To do two things at once is to do neither." It's a great critique of multitasking, isn't it? Often attributed to the Roman writer Publilius Syrus, although, as is often the case with historical quotes, he probably never said it. What I'm interested in, though, is— is it true? I mean, it's clearly true for emailing at the dinner table, texting while driving, or possibly for live tweeting a TED Talk as well. But I'd like to argue that for certain types of activities, doing two, three, or even four things at once is precisely what we should strive for. Look no further than Albert Einstein; in 1905, he published four remarkable scientific papers.

I know this might sound strange, but I believe robots can inspire us to become better humans. I grew up in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, home of Bethlehem Steel. My father was an engineer, and during my childhood, he would teach me how things worked. We built projects together, like model rockets and slot cars. Here's the go-kart we built together. That's me behind the wheel, with my sister and my best friend. One day, when I was about 10, he came home and announced at the dinner table that our next project would be to build a robot.

Sustainability encompasses what, where, and how our seafood is sourced, but the who and why are crucial to me. I want to understand the people behind my meals and the impact we have on each other. I want to know their reasons for fishing and their dependence on the ocean's resources. This understanding transforms how we view seafood, from a mere commodity to a means of ecosystem restoration. It encourages us to celebrate the seafood we’re privileged to enjoy. So, what do we call this? I believe it’s restorative seafood. While sustainability focuses on enduring and maintaining, restorative emphasizes replenishing and progressing.

The starving orphan seeking a second helping of gruel. The spinster wasting away in her tattered wedding dress. The stone-hearted miser plagued by the ghost of Christmas past. More than a century after his death, these remain recognizable figures from the work of Charles Dickens. So striking is his body of work that it gave rise to its own adjective. But what are the features of Dickens's writing that make it so special? Dickens’s fiction brims with anticipation through brooding settings, plot twists, and mysteries. These elements kept his audience wanting more. Initially, his stories were serialized, released a few chapters at a time in affordable literary journals, and only later reprinted as books.

I want to tell you about the future of money. Let's start with a story about a culture in Micronesia in the early 1900s, known as the Yap. I want to discuss the Yap because their form of money is fascinating. They use limestone discs called rai stones. The Yap don't physically move these rai stones or exchange them like we do with coins, because rai stones can become quite massive. The largest is about four tons and 12 feet across. Instead, the Yap track ownership of sections of each stone. There's a story about sailors transporting a stone across the ocean when they encountered trouble and the stone fell in.

You’ve been accused of a crime you did not commit. It’s impossible to prove your innocence. If you insist that you’re innocent anyway, you’ll likely be found guilty and executed. But if you confess, apologize, and implicate others for good measure, you’ll go free. Do you give a false confession— or risk a public hanging? This was the choice facing those accused of witchcraft in the village of Salem, Massachusetts between February 1692 and May 1693. They were the victims of paranoia about the supernatural, misdirected religious fervor— and a justice system that valued repentance over truth. Salem was settled in 1626 by Puritans, a group of English Protestants. Life was strict and isolated for the people of Salem. Battles with their Native American neighbors and groups of French settlers were commonplace.

There are currently hundreds of thousands of people on transplant lists, waiting for critical organs like kidneys, hearts, and livers that could save their lives. Unfortunately, there aren’t nearly enough donor organs available to meet that demand. What if, instead of waiting, we could create brand-new, customized organs from scratch? That’s the idea behind bioprinting, a branch of regenerative medicine currently under development. While we’re not able to print complex organs just yet, simpler tissues, including blood vessels and tubes responsible for nutrient and waste exchange, are already within reach. Bioprinting is a biological cousin of 3D printing, a technique that deposits layers of material on top of one another to construct a three-dimensional object slice by slice.

On October 4, 1957, the world watched in awe and fear as the Soviet Union launched Sputnik, the world's first man-made satellite, into space. This small metal sphere, less than two feet in diameter, initiated a space race between the U.S. and U.S.S.R. that would last for eighteen years and transform the world as we know it. Sputnik was not actually the first piece of human technology to enter space. That distinction belongs to the V-2 rocket used by Germany in missile attacks against Allied cities as a desperate measure in the final years of World War II. It wasn't very effective, but at the war's end, both the U.S. and U.S.S.R. captured the technology and scientists who had developed it, using them for their own projects.

The world's largest and most devastating environmental and industrial project is situated in the heart of the world's largest and most intact forest, Canada's boreal forest. In 1903, the President of the United States went on a three-day camping trip in California’s Yosemite Valley. President Theodore Roosevelt spent nights among towering sequoia trees, camped in a snowstorm, and had extensive discussions around the campfire with his host and guide, the conservationist John Muir. While Roosevelt was a known outdoor enthusiast, Muir invited him for more than just camping; Yosemite was under threat. Although designated protected land in 1864, the valley faced risks of overdevelopment in 1903. This area was central to a long-standing struggle to reserve land for preservation and public use—two objectives that were challenging to achieve. The battle over Yosemite began during the 1849 Gold Rush when miners flocked west, seeking riches in the Sierra Nevada foothills.

Imagine if you could connect your brain to a machine that would provide you with ultimate pleasure for the rest of your life. If you were offered a chance to live this way, would you? That’s the question philosopher Robert Nozick posed through a thought experiment called the Experience Machine. The experiment asks us to imagine a world where scientists have developed a machine that simulates real life while ensuring only pleasurable experiences. The catch? You have to permanently leave reality behind, but you’ll hardly notice. Your experiences will be indistinguishable from reality. Life’s natural ups and downs are replaced with an endless series of ups. Sounds appealing, right?

Where does all the carbon we release go? Carbon follows a natural cycle and is present in all living things: in the soil, oceans, atmosphere, and rocks deep underground. When plants and other organisms die, much of their stored carbon returns to the atmosphere until new plants grow and reabsorb it. Over millions of years, the carbon stored in ancient trees and sea life becomes rock or fossil fuels: coal, oil, and natural gas. Natural events like volcanic eruptions release carbon trapped in rock, and human activities, such as burning fossil fuels, also release prehistoric carbon. Today, humans release around 60 times more carbon than all the volcanoes on the planet each year.

Even nature's seemingly most unsightly creatures hold important secrets. However, who would want a swarm of cockroaches approaching them? One of the greatest distinctions between natural and human technologies is robustness. Robust systems are stable in complex and unfamiliar environments. Remarkably, cockroaches can self-stabilize while traversing rough terrain. When equipped with a jet pack or subjected to a disturbance like an earthquake, their finely tuned legs enable them to maintain stability without using any brainpower. They can navigate complex terrain like grass without becoming destabilized. We discovered a behavior where, due to their shape, they naturally roll to their side to navigate this artificial patch of grass. Robust systems can perform multiple tasks with the same structure. Here's a new behavior we've discovered.
